urn:contentItem:4RKK-7TN0-TXDB-G1J5-00000-00Tas fire threat eases, but danger not gone: Fire Service2008-01-15T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisTas fire threat eases, but danger not gone: Fire Service

While the immediate bushfire threat has eased in Tasmania, the Fire Service is warning the danger is not over.

Most fires around the state are under control, although some are still burning within containment lines.

The acting chief officer of the fire service, Mike Brown says fire fighters will keep patrolling and back burning, with the fire danger set to continue.

"The pattern of weather we're having seems to be that we're getting warm dry weather followed by some hot windy dry weather and with all of it we're getting little, if any rain," he said.

"The rain for the next few days is only going to be in the far south or the west.

"It's still meaning a lot of work for crews with the fires we've got and of course we want to limit any new fires starting."

There were fears yesterday that an east coast forest fire at Goshen about 10 kilometres west of St Helens could threaten the township.

However the Acting Chief Officer of the Fire Service, Mike Brown says the threat has eased.

"There was a lot of ash and smoke blowing over St Helens so it was causing quite a bit of concern there for a while," he said.

"But the news is now that the fire in many places has burnt down to paddocks and crews have been able to control it with the paddocks and in other areas they're putting in bulldozer lines to contain the fire from and do some back burning from.

"And that's been quite successful and they expect to have that all contained by this afternoon."

A fire at Launceston's Cataract Gorge is expected to be extinguished later today.

The blaze broke out yesterday in the Trevallyn Nature Recreation Area and walking tracks around the gorge were closed.

Fire crews contained the fire overnight and district officer, Mark Dobson says it should be out soon.

"Certainly under control, there are a number of hot spots within the control line," he said.

"We've got TFS crews and Parks and Wildlife crews up there currently, they'll be working through the day to continue the blacking out process and hopefully later in the afternoon we should be able to declare that fire is completely extinguished."

urn:contentItem:7V3V-34V0-Y9Y8-S4K5-00000-00Victoria braces for extreme fire conditions2009-02-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisVictoria braces for extreme fire conditions

Victoria is bracing for another day of dangerous fire conditions with temperatures predicted to be in the high 30s and low 40s degrees Celsius, low humidity, and strong winds ahead of a late change.

Four large bushfires continue to burn to the north and east of Melbourne and there are fears that they could flare up and jump containment lines later today.

More than 1,100 firefighters from interstate and overseas have joined local crews to strengthen the fire-fighting effort.

Department of Sustainability and Environment spokesman Kevin Monk says conditions will be hazardous.

"Anything that starts will burn quickly and has the chance to cause more damage to life and property," he said.Fire locations

Several major blazes will be the focus of today's efforts.

Firefighters are trying to strengthen their control over the bushfire near Daylesford, north-west of Melbourne, before the fire danger increases.

The 2,800-hectare blaze and several spotfires have been contained.

Volunteer firefighters will man stations in the Otway Ranges, in south-west Victoria, and extra fire crews from Bega arrived at Tidal River yesterday to help fight the huge fire burning on Wilsons Promontory.

Crews are focusing on protecting Yanakie, Tidal River, and the Promontory Road.

The fire north-east of Won Wron was contained overnight, but concerns remain that it could flare up in the Mullundung Forest.

Extra crews are due to arrive there from East Gippsland and the CFA has warned residents between Yarram and Stradbroke, to be on high alert tomorrow.

Further west, the communities of Neerim, Neerim South, Nayook, and Jindivick, are also being warned to brace themselves for potential flare up in the Bunyip Ridge fire.

Firefighters are trying to contain a forest fire near Warrnambool, in the state's south-west, before a wind change later this morning.

The blaze near Warrnambool has burnt about 100 hectares of the Framlingham Forest, in an area that was burnt in the 2007 fires.

Incident controller Henry Barton says crews are confident containment lines will be in place before a north-westerly wind change comes through about 11.00am AEDT.

Hundreds of schools and child care centres will be closed today because of the bushfire threat.

About 200 government and independent schools and more than 140 kindergartens and child care centres have already decided to remain shut.

Those facilities are listed on the Department of Education's website

urn:contentItem:7V2V-1J20-YBDY-R1XJ-00000-00Severe weather sparks warning - BLACK SATURDAY2009-02-23T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisLOCALPg. 5Severe weather sparks warning - BLACK SATURDAYEwin Hannan

RESIDENTS in fire-prone towns northeast of Melbourne have been warned to be ready to flee this morning as hot, windy weather is forecast to return to Victoria.

The Department of Sustainability and Environment said Victoria was facing ``extreme fire conditions'' with a predicted maximum of 34C for Melbourne today.

``Monday is set to be a high fire danger day with the forecast showing extreme forest fire danger in the Mallee, and very high fire danger -- forest and grassland -- across Victoria, with the exception of East Gippsland,'' DSE state duty officer Andrew Graystone said.

More than 3000 firefighters across the state are battling four major blazes, the Kilmore-Murrindindi Complex North, the Kilmore-Murrindindi Complex South, Bunyip Ridge and Wilson's Promontory.

Authorities said the severe weather could spread fires within both the Kilmore-Murrindindi fire complexes. Residents in the Warburton Valley and Yarra Valley areas are thought to be most at risk if a wind change due late today causes the fire to spread.

The Country Fire Authority yesterday urged residents in the affected areas to implement their fire survival plans.

``If residents in the Warburton Valley make the decision to leave, they should leave early,'' CFA state duty officer Neil Bumpstead said. ``This should be either Sunday evening or early Monday morning.

``If fire does reach the valley, residents who have left should be prepared that they may have to stay away for several days. We cannot stress enough that with limited road access in the Warburton Valley, traffic may become congested. Being on the roads is dangerous during a fire threat.''

In the Enoch Point area, winds are today expected to turn north and northwesterly at speeds of up to 30km/h.

``This means the fire activity in the area is likely to increase,'' Mr Bumpstead said. ``Winds are southwesterly, (they) may blow the current fire in a northeasterly direction, meaning residents in the Eildon, Snobs Creek, Jerusalem Creek, Alexandra, Rubicon, Thornton, Enoch Point and Jamison areas will continue to experience heavy smoke and ash.''

Mr Graystone said crews had been undertaking back burning and had established control lines along the edges of the fire.

``However, extensive areas inside the fire perimeter remain unburnt and there is a possibility the high fire danger and heavy forest fuels, combined with the long drought, could see fire move outside the boundaries,'' he said.

A total fire ban has been declared for today in the state's northwest, northeast, eastern and central districts.

urn:contentItem:458V-5NS0-0197-82D9-00000-00<published>1998-01-22T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:49:04Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>FEATURES; Pg. 12</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Emergency but no police </nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>GLENNIS SLACK-SMITH</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">SO Mr Carr was "distracted by the bushfires" and thus not responsible for the rushed superannuation bill.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> I can only guess the local smoke affected his eyes.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>MATP</p></bodyText></section><p>I was in Narrabri on November 29, the day the devastating Pilliga forest fire was raging.</p><p> About 60km into the forest highway I found it had been closed.</p><p> I set out for Dubbo at 7.30am the next day, called at the fire station to get directions for an alternative route and was told the police had complete authority over traffic control on the highway.</p><p> I visited Narrabri police station and found it closed.</p><p> I was directed by phone to Moree police station.</p><p> They could give no information on the fire, but gave me two numbers to call (from memory one was Gunnedah police, the other Coonabarabran police). Neither of these two numbers answered calls.</p><p> I travelled to Gunnedah, where the police station was unattended.</p><p> I was then diverted to Tamworth police, who were able to suggest that maybe the highway to Coonabarabran was open, maybe not.</p><p> Relying on advice from a service station operator, I took a longer alternative route.</p><p> The responsibility of the Premier is to govern the State.</p><p> I am appalled that a region bigger than the Sydney metropolitan area was not policed, particularly when a state of emergency was developing.</p><p> GLENNIS SLACK-SMITH Dubbo      </p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4PCH-XYH0-TXN5-R0N6-00000-00INSERT1999-10-18T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisTHE GUIDEPg. 23INSERTSundayJane Freeman

WALKING WITH DINOSAURS

ABC, 7pm

IF YOU didn't catch up with the Walking With Dinosaurs phenomenon last week, tune in tonight, especially if you're surrounded by dinosaurophile kids. This show is amazing.

Forget all that stuff about the millions of dollars it cost to make and the high-tech computer animation whiz-bangery, all you really need to know is that you'll become convinced you are actually seeing footage of dinosaurs in action. This illusion is enhanced by a present-tense narrative track that sounds as if you're watching just another nature documentary. And the detail is so exquisite you even see newborn babies have a scratch and their older relatives farting.

Tonight we're in the Jurassic period (152,000,000 BC) when the really huge dinos stomped the forests and plains, followed by a massive army of dung beatles. We follow the fate of a baby diplodicus as she fends off predators, evades a forest fire and, 10 years later, even survives the ordeal of mating. Along the way, you can't help thinking, "How do they know that?" - as in, "How do they know the diplodicus used their tails to communicate?" or "How do they know stegasaurus spines glowed red to repel predators?"

In the end, it doesn't really matter. It's just magic. Even my dog seemed to find the dino noises fascinating. Amazing to see your dog watch "footage" of animals that existed in 152,000,000 BC.

urn:contentItem:7XV5-MXW1-2RG7-218S-00000-00Three decades of Government failure: Commission told2010-02-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisThree decades of Government failure: Commission toldJane Cowan

The Bushfires Royal Commission has heard an impassioned plea from a former forest fire chief to drastically increase the amount of planned burning done in Victoria.

Athol Hodgson was Commissioner of Forests in the 1980s and then chief fire officer of the Department of Conservation, Forests and Lands.

He told the Commission there had been a "failure to provide a safe environment" to Victorians over three decades.

He said the Victorian Government had allowed fuel loads to accumulate to "unnatural" levels so that it was now impossible to stop fires unless firefighters were virtually standing next to them when they ignited.

Mr Hodgson implored the Commission to recommend that Victoria almost triple the amount of fuel reduction burning done and enshrine the targets in legislation so performance can be accurately assessed.

The Commission heard the current department, the Department of Sustainability and Environment (DSE) currently burns less than two percent of its forests to reduce fuels.

This is despite its own corporate plan which sets up to three times that percentage as a desirable target.

But the DSE today defended the amount of fuel reduction burning carried out.

The DSE's secretary, Greg Wilson, said the larger figure was only a "light on the hill" to be aspired to in the long term.

He played down the success of Western Australia's extensive fuel reduction burning program, saying things were more complex in Victoria.

Asked to respond to evidence the full-time firefighting workforce had shrunk from 1,500 in the 1980s to only several hundred now, Mr Wilson conceded the workforce needed to increase but said it was adequate to meet current burn targets.

'Shameful' staffing levels

Earlier, the Royal Commission was told the Victorian Government broke a Bracks-era promise to boost the number of forest firefighters.

The Commission heard the Victorian Government announced an extra 151 extra permanent DSE field crew to be provided over four years, but only 23 were ever appointed.

The Commission was told the promise was made in 2004 when Steve Bracks was Premier.

The Australian Workers Union's Cesar Melhem, who represents DSE firefighters, said Victoria was still waiting for the other 128.

Mr Melhem said current staffing levels needed to be tripled to meet the government's own targets for how much fuel reduction burning should be done each year, and should ideally be increased ten-fold.

He said existing staffing levels were "shameful" said too many of the existing staff were desk-bound rather than being on-the-ground firefighters.

He told the hearing that Victoria is "tragically unprepared" for another Black Saturday.

Lawyers for the Victorian Government did not challenge Mr Melhem's evidence.

urn:contentItem:7V3D-FV40-YBDY-R06D-00000-00Fight continues as horror day looms Friday may be another shocker2009-02-25T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Fight continues as horror day looms Friday may be another shocker

FIREFIGHTERS are still battling blazes on Melbourne's eastern fringes and in central Victoria ahead of what could be another horror day on Friday.

The Country Fire Authority has been able to downgrade urgent situations at Upwey in the Dandenong Ranges and at Daylesford northwest of Melbourne, but has warned residents to be alert.

At Upwey, a fire that started in the Birdlands Reserve on Monday has been contained but the CFA has warned residents in adjacent areas to be on the lookout for flying embers in the tinder-dry conditions.

``Even though the fire is not currently posing a threat, the communities of Upwey north of Glenfern Rd need to be aware that fire activity in the area has increased and has the potential to impact directly,'' the CFA said.

CFA spokesman Kevin Monk said ground and air crews were working to prevent any spotting of the fire.

He said 400 firefighters were at Daylesford, 110km northwest of Melbourne, attempting to contain a forest fire spread over 2800 hectares.

``We've got dozers working on that and that's where we may get some spots under the southerly conditions,'' Mr Monk said.

``The conditions are so dry that it only takes a small spark and the fire can race off.''

At Warburton, east of Melbourne, the threat eased after firefighters battled to get on top of that blaze.

But Mr Monk warned that conditions were likely to deteriorate on Friday with temperatures tipped to top 38 degrees combined with strong northerly winds and a south-westerly change.

``Those conditions are always a concern for us and the possibility of new fires starting is a worry,'' Mr Monk said.

``People in the community really need to be on alert for the day.''

Premier John Brumby said only rain can snuff out the fires.

He said it was a miracle the blaze threatening Upwey was contained with minimal damage to property.

``Last night was a miraculous effort really by the firefighters and they just did a fantastic job,'' he said yesterday.

Mr Brumby said Friday was going to be another bad day for firefighters, with scorching heat set to return as 1000km of fire fronts continued to burn.

``(It's) nothing like February 7 in terms of temperature or wind but nevertheless we're looking at something at the top end of the 30s and in the north of the state the low 40s,'' he said.

urn:contentItem:7V02-JY71-2RG6-Y01B-00000-00Nation's top fire chiefs discuss tactics2009-02-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisThe World Today12:26 PM AESTABCBrendan TrembathNation's top fire chiefs discuss tactics

BRENDAN TREMBATH: The heads of fire services across the country have held a national hook-up to discuss the emergency, and determine where fire fighting resources should be deployed.

The meeting was organised by Euan Ferguson, the head of the South Australian Country Fire Service and he joins us on the line now.

Well Mr Ferguson, what's been agreed to?

EUAN FERGUSON: Well, I suppose the first thing was we expressed our condolences for all those affected by the fire. In particular, the response agencies in Victoria who, whilst they got a very clear task, would be affected very deeply by what's going on around them.

We had a discussion and a very quick briefing on the overall situation. We don't fight Victoria's fires for them, but it's important that the national fire fighting resources are applied in the area of highest risk. So this is actually a follow up to a teleconference we had on Friday of last week. As a result of that teleconference, a number of aircraft were moved into Victoria in anticipation of that bad day. We need to recognise that last Friday, South Australia, northern Tasmania, Victoria, ACT and New South Wales all faced extreme fire danger.

This morning we've reiterated various levels of support, both aircraft and firefighters and specialist incident management personnel, which have come from New South Wales, ACT, Tasmania and South Australia. The CEO of the Country Fire Authority, Neil Bibby, gave an indication as to where he sees the situation in the next couple of days.

BRENDAN TREMBATH: What is that? What's the forecast as far as you've been told?

EUAN FERGUSON: Well a number of these fires are now burning deep in forest areas. There is a significant length of control lines that needs to be established, particularly in the areas of public land and heavy forest. That won't be resolved in days. I think the representative from the Department of Sustainability and Environment indicated that they're now indicated at looking at a couple of weeks perhaps before they secure all these control lines.

That in turn will allow agencies elsewhere to plan relief for their firefighters who are currently deployed in Victoria and perhaps provide some specific support for deep forest fire fighting.

BRENDAN TREMBATH: Euan Ferguson, we'll have to leave it there. Thank you very much for your time.

Euan Ferguson from the South Australian Country Fire Service involved in the national hook-up of fire fighting chiefs today.

'WildFire'</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">"WILDFIRE" is poised to hit the rural south this summer and the</p><p nitf:lede="true">Country Fire Services (CFS) is out to spread the word.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The CFS has renamed all out-of-control fires as WildFire, in a bid to</p><p nitf:lede="true">help people realise the danger they are facing.</p><p>"This year we are calling the danger 'WildFire' not bushfire, or</p><p>grass fire, or forest fire or farm fire, but Wildfire and you must</p><p>prepare yourself for the worst," CFS Chief Executive Officer Stuart</p><p>Ellis stressed in a media statement.</p><p>The move comes after a recent survey revealed that 78 per cent of</p><p>rural and hills residents did not believe their properties faced a</p><p>high fire danger risk.</p><p>The CFS has blamed the blase attitude of the locals on the tame terms</p><p>used to describe fires in the past.</p><p>"The reality is that the majority of rural property and hills zone</p><p>residents are at risk and therefore must prepare themselves for the</p><p>worst," Mr Ellis said.</p><p>"The CFS strategy therefore was to highlight that when a fire gets</p><p>out of control it becomes wild and we are all in danger."</p><p>The CFS, in a joint effort with local councils, will attempt to mail</p><p>out WildFire information to assist rural residents in devising</p><p>individual action plans for their properties.</p><p>WildFire information is also available from all councils and CFS</p><p>regional offices.</p><p>Bonfire ban creates headache for local man, page 17.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:5MJT-N691-JCM0-64VN-00000-00Lightning, tornadoes and mice: the science of bushfires2017-01-06T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisLightning, tornadoes and mice: the science of bushfiresJames Bullen

They're a familiar sight on the Australian landscape as the weather warms - cutting a path of destruction through homes, farmland, and the bush.

But bushfires have also played an important role in the cycle of renewal undergone by the Australian landscape for millennia.

How does a bushfire begin and spread, and what happens to the environment once it's moved through?

A fire starts when three elements - oxygen, a fuel source, and an ignition source - come together. But not every blaze will become a bushfire. The more dry, hot, and windy it is, the greater the risk a blaze will take off and spread, pushed forward by the wind.

Peak fire conditions occur when there's a period of significant rainfall that causes plants to grow, followed by a hot spell that dries out this fuel. This means the bushfire seasons vary around Australia.

In the north of the country, bushfires are more likely to appear in winter and spring, but in southern states like Victoria and Tasmania bushfires are more likely in summer and autumn.

How bushfires move

Bushfires typically move in a front - a thin line of burning grass or forest that inches forward as new material catches alight.

Radiant heat from the fire front warms the air ahead, drying out fuel, and causing volatile gases inside wood to escape - thus priming new fuel for the approaching fire.

Grass fires are generally wind driven and spread quickly - moving up to 20 kilometres per hour, according to Dr Jason Sharples from the Bushfire and Natural Hazards Cooperative Research Centre.

Forest fires may burn hotter but, because there's more fuel for them, they advance slower than grass fires.

"In the most extreme fire conditions you're still only looking at a rate of spread of a couple of kilometres per hour," said Dr Sharples, adding that 3-4 kilometres per hour would be considered very fast for a forest fire.

And fires move more quickly up a hill than down one.

That's because going uphill, the flames are much closer to new fuel and spread easily, while it's the opposite going down.

'Deep flaming' and fire storms

Strong winds can sometimes blow burning embers ahead of the fire front, setting alight new patches of fuel in a process known as "spotting".

These patches of fire can then quickly grow and join up, forming one giant blaze, hundreds of metres or even kilometres wide. Such an event, known as "deep flaming", is more difficult for firefighters to control.

The heat and smoke given off from deep flaming can even create "pyrocumulonimbus" clouds that form over a bushfire.

Sometimes these clouds create thunderstorms, fuelling lightning strikes that can in turn start new fires.

"If you're not getting any rain out of your thunderstorm, and you're just getting lightning hitting dry fuel, it's just another source of ignition," Dr Sharples said.

On rare occasions, "fire tornadoes" can even result from pyrocumulonimbus clouds. These tornadoes form in the same way as regular tornadoes - a combination of wind shear, hot moist air, and cold dry air - only in this case, those conditions arise from the bushfire itself.

Dr Sharples said a fire tornado appeared during Canberra's 2003 bushfires, in which four people were killed and more than 400 buildings destroyed. The tornado was responsible for destroying a number of houses on Canberra's edge.

How are animals affected by bushfires?

Animals may survive bushfires if they can escape the area and recolonise it later. Another option is to hide from the fire.

Even in intense forest fires, the shock of the heat only lasts a matter of minutes, giving animals a chance to make it through, said Professor Ross Bradstock, also from the Bushfire and Natural Hazards CRC.

"If you're a small reptile that uses burrows in the soil or even hollows in trees, you may be able to hide," he said.

"If you're a koala or large possum that's arboreal, you're very vulnerable."

In the aftermath of a fire, some animals starve to death waiting for plants to grow back, while others may become more vulnerable to predators because they have fewer places to hide.

What about plants?

Professor Bradstock said in the days and weeks following a bushfire many plants drop new seeds, while others will quickly re-sprout.

"Even though their foliage may be completely consumed, they haven't died," he said.

"Some plants have the ability to regrow from protected buds."

Others have exceptionally thick bark, which may be scorched but still protects the vulnerable vascular plant material beneath.

Grasses and other plants also have extensive root systems beneath the ground that can help them regrow if they've been burnt off.

These "resilience and persistence mechanisms" are present in most Australian flora, Professor Bradstock said.

"Most of our environments in Australia have been subjected to fire for not just millennia, but timescales well beyond that. So even in rainforests on the mainland, you'll find plants can re-sprout after the occasional fire," he said.

The path to renewal

For many plants, fire is as much a chance at renewal and regrowth as it is a destructive event. In fact, Australian plants have evolved with bushfire to such an extent that some of them can't survive without it.

"Different species have different life cycles, and some of their aspects of reproduction and regeneration may be linked to fire," Professor Bradstock said.

An example of such a plant is the acacia, which requires the heat of a bushfire to crack its seed pods so it can germinate.

Some animals, too, prefer a landscape that's been scorched by fire - like the endangered Hastings river mouse.

"It likes open environments," Professor Bradstock said.

"Once the vegetation has regrown after about five to 10 years it tends to drop out of a system."

In this way, bushfires prompt a boom and bust cycle in animals as vegetation grows and is removed, and various species flourish with the changing ecosystem.

Professor Bradstock said the total time it took for an ecosystem to return to "normality" depended on rainfall and climate.

For example, in the south of Australia, where there is moderate rainfall, there would be substantial regrowth within a year or two.

"If you were looking from a satellite, measuring greenness, you're pretty much back to pre-fire conditions," Professor Bradstock said.

A full recovery, however, usually takes five to 10 years.

Plants that don't have mechanisms to recover from bushfire can be wiped out from particular areas after a big burn. They then rely on seed dispersal from birds or other means to bring them back to the habitat, said Professor Bradstock.

But, he added, most plants without recovery mechanisms are only found in parts of Australia where fire is less common, such as wet and alpine environments in Tasmania.

urn:contentItem:4VG2-HX60-TX4S-M0PM-00000-00Hazy holiday in the capital as coast burns2009-01-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisAPg. 3Hazy holiday in the capital as coast burnsSarina Talip and Alex Rea

Smoke from a massive bushfire on the South Coast blew into Canberra yesterday carried by strong easterly winds, creating a haze over the city.

The fire has burned out 1200ha of the Budawang National Park, 30km from Batemans Bay, since it was sparked by a lightning strike last Tuesday.

Six waterbombing helicopters and 60 firefighters continued to battle the blaze yesterday.

The helicopters, based in Braidwood, have operated continuously during daylight to fight the flames, refuelling while in midair from the town's recreation ground to save time. "The aircraft are slowing the spread of the fire but it's still uncontained," A NSW Rural Fire Service spokesman said.

"There's still some work to do to create a perimeter around that fire and contain it, and firefighters will be working throughout the night and into [today] to achieve that."

The spokesman said recent showers, milder conditions and higher humidity should allow crews to do crucial backburning.

"Given that there are some milder conditions for the next few days, we're hoping to get on top of that fire [before] the forecast of hotter weather later in the week."

But without significant rainfall, the fire is unlikely to be put out quickly.

Firefighters have struggled to deal with the blaze because of its remote location.

The spokesman said volunteers had done a terrific job.

"Given they've worked on the Australia Day long weekend, it's a massive commitment."

Despite its size, the bushfire is not threatening property.

But the Western Distributor Road was closed to all but residents and emergency vehicles, the spokesman said.

The fire has not yet leapt over the Western Distributor Road and remains on the western side. The Kings Highway remains open but motorists have been advised to drive cautiously through smoke.

Further south, a small forest fire was burning in the Bega Valley, 25km from Pambula, but is not threatening property. Meanwhile, in Canberra, traffic was closed on Mugga Lane yesterday as firefighters worked to contain a blaze in the Mugga Tip that started about 4.30pm.

No property was in danger as a result of the fire, with three crews of firemen battling the blaze that stretched to the size of about half a football oval.

Smoke drifted through Tuggeranong, but an Emergency Services Agency spokesman said there was no danger to the neighbouring area, with the smoke declared non-toxic.

The ACT Fire Brigade issued a warning for people to avoid the area near the tip.

urn:contentItem:55CS-XNR1-F0J6-J2PP-00000-00Search for mystery crash driver called off2012-04-12T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisEARLY GENERAL NEWSPg. 10Search for mystery crash driver called off

REGION - On Monday, April 9, police called off their search for a man reportedly trapped in a vehicle between Strathalbyn and Goolwa.

The man was in contact via UHF radio with South Australian Ambulance Service (SAAS) on Sunday, April 9 and advised them his vehicle rolled into a creek bed about 10 kilometres out of Strathalbyn.

That was the only communication emergency services had with him and police said they would not resume the search unless they received more information.

Searchers were unable to find the missing man.

It was unknown if the man was injured.

Weather warning

REGION - Motorists were urged to take care on Victor Harbor Road at Mount Compass and surrounding areas on Friday, April 6, as strong winds blew debris and caused a hazard for drivers.

Motorists were advised to turn on their lights, slow down and drive to the conditions.

Collision

GOOLWA - A car collided with a pedestrian on Cutting Road on the morning of Friday, April 6.

The woman was driving a gold seven seater SUV or similar and was involved in a minor collision with a pedestrian near the RSL club just after midday.

This was not a hit-run collision.

Bike stolen

MILANG - Between Sunday, April 1 and Friday, April 6, thieves stole a motorbike from a back pergola at Milang.

urn:contentItem:4VFC-RGX0-TXX1-F0HN-00000-00IN BRIEF2009-01-24T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisSATURDAYPg. 30IN BRIEF

Stem cell tests

NEW YORK -- A US biotech company says it will this year do the world's first study of stem-cell treatment for spinal cord injury.

Geron Corp in California gained federal permission this week to inject 8-10 paraplegic patients with cells derived from embryonic cells, within two weeks of their injury.

The study is aimed at testing safety, but doctors will also look for signs such as returning sensation or movement.

Mum left ashen

LONDON -- A young mum has been given a 10-month suspended jail term for allowing her son, 3, to smoke.

The boy was was only stopped when a family friend used her mobile phone to film him and alerted social workers.

Dog arson motive

CALIFORNIA -- A serial arsonist started a forest fire that left five firefighters dead as part of a plot to stop his pit bull terrier from being euthanised, a court has heard.

Prosecutors said Raymond Lee Oyler was bent on destruction and started the October 2006 fire in anger that his dog had been impounded.

Oyler, 38, who denies five counts of murder and 40 arson related counts, faces the death penalty if convicted.

War crimes claim

GENEVA -- A UN human rights expert says Israeli military operations in the Gaza Strip raised the spectre of systematic war crimes.

The UN Special Rapporteur on human rights in the Occupied Territories, Richard Falk, said the population were effectively trapped in a war zone and prevented from fleeing, even if they were ill, wounded, or children.

Bombers get life

MANILA -- A Philippines court has convicted three militants and jailed them for life for a 2000 bombing in the capital that killed 11 people.

The December 30, 2000 bombings left a total of 22 dead and about 100 wounded. The court found the three men guilty of the main attack on a train station.

Bernie's cash stash

LONDON -- Formula One boss Bernie Ecclestone faces a desperate legal battle to claw back hundreds of millions of pounds he stashed in offshore bank accounts under his estranged wife's name.

During his marriage to ex-model Slavica, the 78-year-old handed a large proportion of his pound stg. 2.4 billion fortune to his wife, to keep beyond the reach of the taxman.

Now, as the couple prepare for what could be Britain's most expensive divorce, he has instructed his lawyers to try and reclaim the cash. DAILY MAIL

urn:contentItem:4P0N-K0J0-TXN5-S37J-00000-00THE CRATE2004-08-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisENTERTAINMENT GUIDEPg. 6THE CRATECHRIS JOHNSTON

CD REVIEW: Rattlesnakes (1984), Lloyd Cole and the Commotions

It's a strange record, this. On one level it's pretentious twaddle, with all the overt literary references and big, snobby words, and the way Cole sets himself up as a sort of learned bohemian wandering through a charmed life armed only with a cheroot, a Panama hat and an exotic drink, like Oscar Wilde, Jack Kerouac and - horror of horrors - Morrissey. He ponders his difficulties in a heavily laboured manner. He doesn't celebrate anything simply. He's a dandy; he walks the line between the meanest streets and the cleanest A-list parties.

But then, on another level, it's brave and funky and delicate, full of wonderful little moments and, as it turned out listening back to this through the week after many years apart, full of deep, ingrained memories of adolescence.

One thing kept happening, however, during these reconciliation playbacks, and not something I expected or remembered doing in his company before. Laughter. He's funny. I mean, did he mean it when he sang (through his sinuses, in a deep and meaningful way): "Pumped up full of vitamins/On account of all the seriousness/You say you're so happy now/You can hardly stand/Lean over on the bookcase/If you really want to get straight/Read Norman Mailer/Or get a new tailor."? The song is called Are You Ready To Be Heartbroken?, and after listening to it, the answer was, well, yes. I feel primed now. Thanks for that, Lloyd.

I also like Charlotte Street. But only because it's stupid - a guy is doing a crossword in The New York Times (of course), when along comes a mysterious blonde with intense allure, they go back to her place, he never leaves. In the end, the gorgeous Forest Fire is maybe the only song on here devoid of irony. It's about a burning love. Nothing more, nothing less.

urn:contentItem:4TX5-RY60-TXX1-F19Y-00000-00Summer alarm: Geelong countryside `driest since 1982' Dusty dams fire fear2008-11-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Summer alarm: Geelong countryside `driest since 1982' Dusty dams fire fearKERRI-ANN HOBBS

FIRE attack helicopters could be forced to pick up water from Corio Bay because dozens of dams near the Brisbane Ranges are dry.

The extended time away from the fire front could force Country Fire Authority bosses to abandon the assault role of `Elvis' and deploy the aerial tankers to help save homes and buildings, CFA region seven operations manager Bob Barry said.

Up to six super-tankers were also expected to be sent to bushfires to replenish trucks and ground crews, he said.

For the first time, town water may be used to refill tankers and fire trucks.

``Water resources for firefighting services will be extremely limited this year,'' Mr Barry said.

``We will have to cart water into these areas and our helitack aircraft will have to travel further to pluck up water.

``This will have an impact on their ability to operate efficiently in the fire ground.''

Below average spring rain and hot winds had combined to turn rural areas around Geelong, especially from Anakie to Little River, into a fuel-loaded firebomb.

``We are going to experience fast-running grass fires and any forest fire activity that we have will most likely go for longer and have more impact,'' Mr Barry said.

``If we put all those factors together with the predicted extreme fire weather then we have a significant risk.

``I don't want to play this up as if we have a disaster on our hands, but the word we are using is critical.

``If a fire starts we are going to have to deal with it but the fallout from that can be disastrous in the right conditions.''

Jalna Feedlot's David Gillett said the country was the driest he'd seen since 1982. All 27 dams on the 3600ha property between Geelong and Anakie are empty.

Anakie resident Nick Lanham, whose home was lost in the devastating 2005-06 fires, said he had learned lessons from the blaze.

He installed a large rainwater tank near the home for the CFA to use, cleared a 20m buffer around his house and developed a fire plan to allow early evacuation if necessary.

``I guess the worry is that if they (CFA) haven't got enough water to fight a fire that will place me personally at risk again,'' Mr Lanham said.

``I am at a higher risk if the CFA don't have access to fresh water.''

urn:contentItem:5JGN-BPW1-JD34-V498-00000-00Up the creek, with paddle2016-04-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisTRAVELLERPg. 18Up the creek, with paddleAdventure CanadaElspeth Callender

In the far north-west, help can get you safely out of your comfort zone, writes Elspeth Callender.

Two 40-something Australians met up in Canada last July to paddle a 416-kilometre stretch of the Yukon River by themselves. One steered from the back, the other navigated at the bow. They were on the water for up to 12 hours a day, sometimes in strong headwinds. Each evening they scoffed wine and cheese in the virtually ceaseless summer sun before setting up camp. After eight days, one wolverine, three bears and several moose, they arrived in the Yukon's historic Dawson City for a music festival they already had tickets for.

Neither had ever canoed.

The name Yukon derives from the Gwich'in word yu-kun-ah, meaning "great river". From Atlin Lake in British Columbia, North America's fifth-longest river flows for 3185 kilometres - roughly the distance between Melbourne and Cooktown - through the Yukon then the US state of Alaska to the Bering Sea.

Philippa Cox is a midwife who'd spent the previous six months working in an Ethiopian refugee camp and Melinda Stanley is a Brisbane-based lawyer. Friends for years, they periodically converge on interesting places for adventure. This paddling expedition from Carmacks to Dawson, however, swept them further than usual from their respective comfort zones.

"We were so nervous, oh my god," Stanley told me afterwards on the phone. By day four they were both physically and emotionally wrecked, but overcame the pain and found their rhythm. "In the end," she said, "it was the best thing we've ever done."

The logistics of organising a river trip in Canada's far north-west Yukon Territory can seem daunting from Australia, until you understand that the concept of outfitting has been a way of life there since the 19th century, when European pioneers first penetrated the subarctic for fur trading, missionary ventures, scientific expeditions and mineral exploration. Now, companies dedicated to providing and organising the necessary equipment and transfers for independent excursions - from winter camping trips on snowmobiles to midsummer fishing on lakes accessible only by float plane - are just part of the Yukon furniture.

Kanoe People, on the banks of the Yukon River in Whitehorse, was conceived in 1974 and has been owned and operated by the same family since 1987. The territory's capital is so compact you can walk between accommodation, supermarkets, outdoor stores and KP. Last summer, I rented a sea kayak from them for my own Yukon River trip, launching straight off the bank right beside the outfitter.

Yet Cox and Stanley, without the paddling experience or local friends to guide them that I had, really found out what KP has to offer.

"We give people as much information as they want to hear," Scott McDougall tells me. "We point out the highlights, go through the basics, but I don't sugar-coat it. It's real. You gotta keep a smart head and handle your own emergencies."

McDougall is a typical Yukoner: capable, reliable, authentic, kind and quietly wild. "Your No. 1 piece of gear," he reminds people, "is sitting on your shoulders."

Despite being busy over summer, McDougall's daughter spent a couple of hours with the two beginners. "She gave us skills to paddle, read the river and bank up," recalled Cox. "Kanoe People were incredible, especially Emily."

After gold was discovered in 1896 in a tributary of the Klondike River, which flows into the Yukon River at Dawson, the great river became a sternwheeler superhighway when it wasn't frozen over. Consequently, the 736-kilometre stretch between Whitehorse and Dawson - with its First Nations fish camps, simple campgrounds and Klondike-era relics - isn't technically wilderness, but might as well be given the remoteness and awesome fauna.

"Every single thing we encountered was absolutely beautiful and so different," Stanley told me. And I know exactly the landscape she's talking about: a broad flat watercourse; boreal forest of stunted spruce and sweet-scented cottonwood; cut banks and towering river cliffs; sloughing grass with trees, still rooted in the topsoil, angling out over the flow. Eroded rock faces decorated with sculpturic hoodoos, purple fireweed flaming within stands blackened by forest fire, pebbly and sandy beaches, campsite clearings as perfect as film sets, never-ending twilight, glimpses of wildlife.

I ask about who tends to hire KP gear and the answer is "grandma, grandpa, their kids and grandkids". Any recent standouts? That's when I hear about the Australians. Scott McDougall was also at Dawson City Music Festival and tells me the first people he saw were "Pip and Mel", who just about knocked him over with their bear-hugs. "Moments like that," he says, "are really rewarding."

GETTING THERE

Air Canada flies from Sydney and Melbourne to Whitehorse (via Vancouver); aircanada.com. Air North also flies between Vancouver and Whitehorse; see flyairnorth.com.

STAYING THERE

Gold Rush Inn, 411 Main Street, Whitehorse. Rooms from CAN$190 ($247) over summer. See book.bestwestern.com. Aurora Inn, cnr Harper Street & 5th Avenue, Dawson City. Rooms from CAN$149 over summer. See aurorainn.ca.

Elspeth Callender was a guest of Tourism Yukon and Canadian Tourism Commission.

TRIP NOTES MORE

INFORMATION

travelyukon.com

canada.travel

kanoepeople.com

urn:contentItem:4PPH-2SR0-TX5K-9190-00000-00Top job a good Fitz2007-09-19T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisPg. 11Top job a good Fitz

WHEN a fresh-faced Shane Fitzsimmons signed up with the Duffys Forest fire brigade at the tender age of 15, he thought it would help him stay on the straight and narrow.

Surrounded by men much older than him, Mr Fitzsimmons learned the art of firefighting and the value of teamwork and leadership.

Those lessons paid off yesterday with Mr Fitzsimmons, 38, was named as the new NSW Rural Fire Service Commissioner.

He has been acting in the position since his predecessor, Phil Koperberg, announced he was opting for a political career last year.

Mr Fitzsimmons, of Berowra, has received several awards during his career, including a life membership of the Duffys Forest brigade.

He said it was ''a privilege and an honour'' to be appointed commissioner and is confident the coming fire season won't be too harsh.

''My commitment is going to be servicing the volunteers in going about their business and ensuring with government that we work on providing the resources where they're needed and when they are needed,'' he said.

Mr Fitzsimmons told the Daily it seemed natural to become a volunteer firefighter at 15.

''I followed my old man into the organisation and it just became a hobby,'' he said.

''It was a great avenue for me to develop life skills and give something to the community so I didn't end up too wayward in my youth.''

Mr Fitzsimmons confessed he couldn't remember fighting his first fire but a couple of blazes stood out, including the infamous 1994 inferno that circled Sydney.

''We were first deployed to the north coast but we had to get back when a fire started at Cottage Point and went right to the edge of Warringah,'' he said.

''You are anxious fighting fires. ''People talk about the adrenalin rush but it's a case of putting in place the things you are trained for.''

Mr Fitzsimmons inherits a fire service that became much more professional under Mr Koperberg's tenure.

''Back when I joined, you bought your own overalls, went to the army disposal store for boots and had to sew your own patches,'' Mr Fitzsimmons said.

''Mr Koperberg was a pioneer for the Rural Fire Service. His departure leaves some significant boots to fill.''

urn:contentItem:4P8B-RNY0-TXN5-T1K5-00000-00LOCAL HERO ON MISSION IMPOSSIBLE2000-08-29T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 11LOCAL HERO ON MISSION IMPOSSIBLETHE WORDaccording to Chad Watson and James Joyce

A LAKE Macquarie man has an integral role in the fight against the United States' worst fires in more than a century.

Paul McBain, NSW State Forest fire manager for the Hunter Region, is among 82 Australians battling against 2million hectares ablaze across the Rocky Mountain Range in the American West.

They were flown in by the US Government in a desperate bid to control 2000 fires most sparked from lightning strikes burning through Montana and Idaho, Wyoming and elsewhere for the past two months.

McBain, who lives at Belmont North, is on the frontline.

Stationed near Missoula in north-western Montana, he's been working 18 hours a day for 14 days straight.

Fairfax correspondent and former Newcastle Herald journalist Mark Riley said it was `bizarre' to stumble across McBain in the remote area.

`Here I am in some of the most dense scrub you're ever likely to find in your life and up pops a Newcastle bloke,' Riley said. `It was really quite unbelievable.'

McBain (pictured, third from left, in Koutenai National Park) told our Wordsmith that it was almost impossible to beat bushfires of this magnitude.

`You've just got to try and out-think it,' McBain explained.

But the Americans are stoked with the assistance being provided by the Aussie contingent.

`They are excellent, well-trained, go-get-'em firefighters,' said Gary Berndt, head of the Missoula fire strategy team.

McBain (pictured, third from left, in Koutenai National Park)

urn:contentItem:5D77-G7S1-F0JP-W1YG-00000-00Flick through the best of holiday films2014-09-27T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 60Flick through the best of holiday filmsLEIGH PAATSCH

Head for the big screens with the kids to make the most of the school holidays with this movie guide by LEIGH PAATSCH.

GUARDIANS OF THE GALAXY (M, 121 min) Now showing Who?: Chris Pratt, Zoe Saldana, and the voices of Bradley Cooper, Vin Diesel. What?: Sci-fi adventure-comedy. A group of reformed space criminals must work together to stop a fanatic from destroying the galaxy.

Well?:The latest release from Marvel Entertainment is already one of the biggest films of 2014, and stands up well to repeat viewing. The M-rating is slightly deceptive, as a majority of scenes (save for the occasional explosion) are well inside the all-ages zone.

Which age group?: Under 5yo: * 1/2 5yo - 8yo: * * * 9yo - 12yo: * * * * 13yo+: * * * * THE BOXTROLLS (PG, 99 min) Now showing Who?: Voices of Isaac Hampstead Wright, Jared Harris, Ben Kingsley, Elle Fanning.

What?: Stop-motion animation. A young orphan raised by sewer-dwelling trash collectors tries to save his friends from an evil exterminator. Based on the novel Here Be Monsters by Alan Snow.

Well?: A strikingly animated production from the makers of the recent surprise hits Coraline and ParaNorman.

If your kids could handle the creepier material that surfaced in those films, they should have no problems here.

Otherwise, easily spooked young children might be better sent elsewhere. Which age group?: Under 5yo: * * 5yo - 8yo: * * * 9yo - 12yo: * * * 1/2 13yo+: * * * TEENAGE MUTANT NINJA TURTLES (M, 112 min) Now showing Who?: Megan Fox, Will Arnett, Whoopi Goldberg and the voices of Johnny Knoxville, Tony Shalhoub.

What?: Action adventure. With the help of an intrepid news reporter, a group of mutated warriors face off against an evil kingpin who wants to take over New York.

Well?: The Turtles are back, but not in the family-friendly guise that most 90s nostalgists would fondly remember. The combat scenes are too violent and threatening for children, while the sleazy asides of the Turtles when co-star Megan Fox slinks into frame are an unwelcome bonus.

Which age group?: Under 5yo: * 5yo - 8yo: * 9yo - 12yo: * 1/2 13yo+: * * PLANES: FIRE & RESCUE (G, 80 min) Now showing Who?: Voices of Dane Cook, Julie Harris, Julie Bowen, Brad Garrett. What?: Animation sequel. When Dusty learns that his engine is damaged and he may never race again, he joins a forest fire and rescue unit to be trained as a firefighter.

Well?: Doesn't happen often, but this spritely and involving sequel marks a dramatic improvement upon a so-so original. With so few low-impact titles in release for very young viewers this holiday period, this will be a reliable choice for most parents.

Which age group?: Under 5yo: * * * 1/2 5yo - 8yo: * * * 9yo - 12yo: * * * 13yo+: * * THE MAZE RUNNER (M, 117 min) Now showing Who?: Dylan O'Brien, Will Poulter, Aml Ameen, Kaya Scodelario. What?: Action adventure. Thomas is deposited in a community of boys after his memory is erased, soon learning they're all trapped in a maze that will require him to join forces with fellow "runners" for a shot at escape.

Well?: The M-rating is fully warranted with violence and a few threatening scenes, which means it should be kept away from youngsters. For boys 10 and over, though, this gripping chase flick will deservedly be their must-see of the holidays.

Which age group?: Under 5yo: * 5yo - 8yo: * 1/2 9yo - 12yo: * * * 13yo+: * * * 1/2 THE HOUSE OF MAGIC (G, 85 min) Now showing Who?: Voices of Cinda Adams, George Babbit, Murray Blue.

What?: Animated adventure. Seeking shelter from a storm, a cheeky and loveable cat named Thunder sneaks into a mysterious mansion owned by retired magician "The Illustrious Lorenzo".

Well?: A quick-paced bundle of fun for under-10s. Made in Belgium (voiced in English), this doesn't follow the Hollywood lead of cramming scenes full of sight gags and chatty voice talent. Refreshing.

Which age group?: Under 5yo: * * * 1/2 5yo - 8yo: * * * 9yo - 12yo: * * 1/2 13yo+: * THE GIVER (M, 97 min) Now showing Who?: Brenton Thwaites, Jeff Bridges, Meryl Streep, Odeya Rush. What?: Drama. In a seemingly perfect community, without suffering a young boy is chosen to learn from an elderly man about the true pain and pleasure of the "real" world.

Well?: The best aspects of this intriguing future-shock drama will go right over the heads of kids under 10.

But there is plenty of quality food-for-thought for the rest of the youth demographic, especially those impatiently waiting for the next Hunger Games.

Which age group?: Under 5yo: * 5yo - 8yo: * * 9yo - 12yo: * * *13yo+: * * * 1/2

urn:contentItem:5B20-TR01-F03R-N326-00000-002013 Looking Back: Greatest Moments of the Year on Twitter2013-12-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexis2013 Looking Back: Greatest Moments of the Year on TwitterSounak Mukhopadhyay

Dec 13, 2013 (International Business Times Australia:http://au.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex)
A plane tows an R.I.P. sign over an unofficial memorial event for "Fast Furious" star Paul Walker in Santa Clarita, California December 8, 2013.


Twitter, as a social networking microblogging platform, emerged wonderfully in 2013. It proved that news could spread faster than forest fire when posted on this platform. The 140-character world turned out to be extraordinary for many reasons. Kurt Wagner of Mashable.com threw light on some of those.
Top Tweets of the Year 'Glee' actor Cory Monteith passed away in July. His college Lea Michele left a short note along with an intimate photograph saying goodbye to Monteith. It was retweeted over 400,000 times in more than 130 countries.

Thank you all for helping me through this time with your enormous love support. Cory will forever be in my heart. pic.twitter.com/XVlZnh9vOc[1]
— Lea Michele (@msleamichele) July 29, 2013[2]

'Fast and Furious' start Paul Walker's death in a car accident was not only shocking but also devastating for many. The news of his death was announced through Walker's Twitter account. The confirmation was retweeted over 400,000 times falling a little short of Michele's tweet to finish second on the list of the most retweeted.
It's with a heavy heart that we must confirm Paul Walker passed away today in a tragic car accident...MORE: http://t.co/9hDuJMH99M[3] - #TeamPW[4] — Paul Walker (@RealPaulWalker) December 1, 2013[5]

The third in the list is much lighter in approach. Niall Horan expressed his ecstasy of turning 20. The 'One Direction' star was overjoyed that he was no more a teenager. His birthday tweet was retweeted 375,292 times.

Yesss ! I'm 20 ! Wohooo ! No more teens!
— Niall Horan (@NiallOfficial) September 12, 2013[6]

Twitter Debut 2013 saw some of the major international names making their Twitter debut. The list of debutants includes former U.S. presidents George H W Bush and Bill Clinton. Other significant names include Roger Federer, Kobe Bryant and Joe Montana. Business tycoons Warren Buffett tweeted just four times in 2013 but his list of followers has over 720,000 names. Major Moments on Twitter The new pope was welcomed on Twitter. Pope Francis was introduced to the world in March.
A su Santidad Francisco I pic.twitter.com/a1ujwamYmk[7] — Cristina Kirchner (@CFKArgentina) March 13, 2013[8]

Millions mourned at the death of the former president of South Africa, Nelson Mandela. About 7.2 million tweets mentioned Mandela's death.

'Death is something inevitable.When a man has done what he considers to be his duty to his peoplehis country,he can rest in peace' #Madiba[9]
— NelsonMandela (@NelsonMandela) December 5, 2013[10]

The breaking news of Boston Marathon Bombings created ripple on Twitter. Over 27 million tweets were posted on the topic.
BREAKING NEWS: Two powerful explosions detonated in quick succession right next to the Boston Marathon finsh line this afternoon. — The Boston Globe (@BostonGlobe) April 15, 2013[11]

The U.S. government had to be shut down for budget constraints. The 16-day shutdown generated millions of tweets.

A government shutdown will have a real impact on real people right away—and the House is hours away from forcing one. #EnoughAlready[12]
— Barack Obama (@BarackObama) September 30, 2013[13]

urn:contentItem:4P0W-XC40-TXN5-T31R-00000-00Just to start the day right2003-12-30T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisSUPPLEMENTPg. 46Just to start the day rightsummer herald

A photographer for a newspaper was assigned to get photos of a big forest fire, but the smoke at the scene was too thick, so he called his office to hire a plane.

"It will be waiting for you at the airport," said the editor, "Hurry."

As soon as the

photographer got to the small airport he saw a plane warming up on the runway so he jumped in with his equipment and yelled, "Let's go".

The pilot swung the plane into the wind and they were airborne. "Fly over the north side of the fire," he said, "and make three of four low-level passes." "Why?" said the pilot.

"Because I'm a photographer, and photographers take pictures," he said with exasperation.

After a pause, the pilot said, "You mean you're not the

instructor?"

Q: What did the water say to the boat?

A: Nothing, it just waved.

A shy man goes into a bar and sees a beautiful woman sitting alone. He gathers up his courage for an hour, then goes over to her and asks tentatively, "Would you mind if I chatted to you for a little while?" To which she responds by yelling at the top of her lungs: "No, I won't sleep with you."

Hopelessly embarrassed and with everyone in the bar looking at him, the man slinks back to his table. A little while later the woman walks over to him and apologises.

"I'm sorry if I embarrassed you. You see, I'm a journalist and I have an assignment to see how people react to embarrassing situations."

To which the man yells: "What do you mean, $400?"

Q: What do you get when you cross a snowman with a vampire?

A: Frostbite.

How many journalists does it take to change a lightbulb?

"We just report the facts. We don't change them."

urn:contentItem:3T73-GK40-0048-T2D1-00000-00<published>1998-07-23T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:49:04Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>WORLD NEWS IN BRIEF</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">LEONE AMPUTEES</p><p nitf:lede="true"> FREETOWN, July 22 Reuters - Dozens of men, women and children who had limbs hacked off by rebels opposed to Sierra Leone's reinstated president protested in the capital Freetown to demand greater help, witnesses said.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The protesters gathered outside the Department of Rehabilitation, Reconstruction and Resettlement yesterday to demand an increase in food rations at the Waterloo camp, where they are staying outside the city.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> They said more than 300 amputees were gathered in the camp, living off a cup of rice and 300 leones (under $ A.16) a day and a pint of cooking oil and a cup of corn flour a month.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "This is an insult to our humanity," one amputee, Joseph Mgaojia, told reporters.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p>GREECE FIRES</p><p> ATHENS, July 22 Reuters - Three Greek firemen were burned to death today as they fought to stop a forest fire from reaching a busy Athens suburb.</p><p> "They were found about 10 metres from their fire engine, which had run out of water," a police spokesman said.</p><p> About 30 firemen were battling the blaze in the mountains over the Athens suburb of Ilioupolis, trying to keep it away from the densely populated area.</p><p> Another forest fire fanned by strong winds burned homes in the holiday town of Saronida, about 40km south-east of Athens, and the fire department ordered its evacuation.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p>RUSSIA ARMS EXPORTS</p><p> MOSCOW, July 22 AP - Weapons account for 80 per cent of Russia's industrial exports, and are expected to reach $ US3.5 billion ($ A5.61 billion) this year, the head of state-run arms exporter said in a newspaper article published today.</p><p> "Weapons today are the most high-tech product exported by Russia," Rosvooruzheniye chief Yevgeny Ananyev wrote.</p><p>Russia plans to deliver weapons to 59 countries this year, Ananyev said. The $ US3.5 billion ($ A5.61 billion) they will bring in is an increase of $ US1 billion ($ A1.60 billion) over 1997, he said.</p><p> The United States has criticised Russia for selling arms to volatile regions, but Moscow has shrugged off the complaint as a double standard on the part of Washington.</p><p>AP</p><p> POPE HOLIDAY</p><p> VATICAN CITY, July 21 AFP - Pope John Paul II gave his first audience today, after returning early to the Vatican from his two week vacation in the Italian Alps.</p><p> The Pope, who returned from his two week break by helicopter for the audience went to his residence at Castelgandolfo, to the south of Rome.</p><p> He appeared to be in good health after his vacation in the village of Lorenzago, in the Cadore Valley, the heart of the Dolomite mountains.</p><p> During the summer, the Pope intends to finish editing his volume on the relationship between faith and reason at the dawn of the third millennium. "Fides et Ratio" is expected to be published in October.</p><p>AFP</p><p>SYRIA GANG</p><p> DAMASCUS, July 22 Reuters - Three wanted Syrian criminals were killed in central Damascus today during a clash with police which ended with the gang's car exploding, police sources said.</p><p> They said that security men in cars, in a rare incident in the quiet streets of Damascus, chased the three in the city around noon and exchanged fire with them after they refused to stop.</p><p> One source said the shooting took place as the hunted men reached the Ain al-Karsh area, in central Damascus close to the Central Bank and the Finance Ministry.</p><p> During the exchange, the petrol tank of the criminals' car exploded, killing the three men instantly, the source said, adding that no one else was injured.</p><p>REUTERS</p><p>GERMANY PLOT</p><p> HALBERSTADT, Germany, July 22 AFP - A politician from Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Union (CDU) party is suspected of having hired killers to eliminate someone to whom he owed money, prosecutors said here today.</p><p> Manfred Wulfert, 48, is treasurer for the CDU branch in the eastern state of Saxony-Anhalt.</p><p> "We have opened an inquiry into Mr Wulfert for concerted action towards a murder," prosecutor Hauke Roggenbuck said in this eastern town.</p><p> "No one has been killed," he added, also noting that it was a private affair not involving party funds.</p><p> The politician has pleaded innocent.</p><p>AFP</p><p> ENDS WORLD DATELINES    <br/></p><p> AAP gl</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3T73-GK40-0048-T2D1-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-25</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="703"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:52J7-9T61-DYTG-211M-00000-00Warning of huge rise in risk of bushfire2011-04-05T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisAPg. 4Warning of huge rise in risk of bushfireSurge in extreme danger days as a result of climate changeRosslyn BeebyScience and Environment Reporter

Australia's bushfire risk will increase by 25 per cent in less than a decade if climate change pushes up average temperatures by just 0.4 degrees by 2020, according to CSIRO research.

But that risk could more than double by 2020, with the number of extreme fire danger days increasing by up to 65 per cent, if average temperatures rise by one degree, CSIRO climate scientist Kevin Hennessey said.

In a newly published CSIRO collection of peer-reviewed research outlining the climate challenges facing Australia, Dr Hennessey said it was likely the world would see a 2-degree rise in global temperatures "on top of changes already experienced within the lifetime of a current generation".

He said Australia's cities would also feel the impacts of climate change through an increasing "urban heat island effect" caused by the heat-retaining building materials and road infrastructure "putting more demand on energy for air- conditioning".

Climate Change: Science and Solutions for Australia, which can be downloaded as a free e-book from the CSIRO website, was launched yesterday by CSIRO chief executive Megan Clark at a national climate conference in Cairns. Dr Clark said the book was based on the latest peer-reviewed literature on climate change, "contributed by thousands of researchers in Australia and internationally".

In his opening address to the conference, Federal Climate Change Minister Greg Combet said debate on the issue "must move beyond the baseless attacks on the science of climate change," to allow better understanding of its complexity.

"The Australian public deserves better," Mr Combet said.

"Australian scientists have long been respected for making strong contributions to the robust evidence on which we base our climate change policies ...

"Unfortunately though, the confusion in the community has in part been fuelled by a small number of scientists and commentators few of whom have relevant credentials continuing to question the climate change science, even as evidence to the contrary grows in strength."

In his chapter of the CSIRO book, Dr Hennessey said climate change impacts would increasingly "be experienced first through extreme events rather than gradual changes in mean temperature or rainfall".

He said conditions leading to the February 2009 Black Saturday bushfires in Victoria were extreme, with high temperatures, low humidity, strong winds, and very dry fuel as a result of years of drought. All these factors combined to produce an extreme forest fire danger index that exceeded 100 in many areas.

When this index is greater than 50, the risk is rated extreme and a total fire ban is declared but the circumstances leading to the Black Saturday fires had resulted in a new fire rating catastrophic being added to the index rating system.

Dr Hennessey said research showed the fire index was "trending upwards" in some areas of southern Australia as a result of higher temperatures and worsening drought.

BRIEFS</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Report of sect massacre</p><p nitf:lede="true">BEIJING -- More than 10 followers of the banned Falun Gong meditation sect were beaten to death in a labour camp in north-eastern China, the sect said yesterday.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Officials at Changlinzi labour camp in Heilongjiang Province and labour camp supervisors in the provincial capital, Harbin, denied the report.</p><p>General to surrender</p><p>ZAGREB -- Croatian army general Rahim Ademi is ready to surrender to authorities if indicted to appear before the UN War Crimes Tribunal in The Hague, President Stipe Mesic said yesterday.</p><p> General Ademi is said to be one of two named in sealed indictments served by the tribunal a month ago.</p><p>South Korea-Japan dispute</p><p>SEOUL -- South Korea froze military exchanges with Japan yesterday as it stepped up a dispute over controversial Japanese history books.</p><p> The defence ministry said the chairman of the joint chiefs of staff had cancelled a visit to Japan.</p><p> The measure was the first announced since Japan told South Korea and China this week that it would not revise eight school textbooks accused of whitewashing Japan's militarist past.</p><p> Airlock for space station</p><p>CAPE CANAVERAL -- The shuttle Atlantis blasted off for the International Space Station yesterday to install a 6.5-tonne airlock that will allow station crew to perform space walks.</p><p> Years of work remain before the station is complete but once the $330 million airlock is installed the orbiting outpost will be a fully functioning space station.</p><p> Firefighters killed</p><p>SEATTLE -- Four firefighters were killed and six others injured in a forest fire in Washington State.</p><p> The blaze, believed started by an unattended camp fire, exploded out of control and engulfed firefighters in the nation's deadliest fire since 1994.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:57FW-GYB1-JD3N-555M-00000-00Homes threatened as 135 blazes rage NSW2013-01-09T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 6Homes threatened as 135 blazes rage NSW

DOZENS of homes remained under threat last night despite the efforts of more than 1000 firefighters battling 135 fires in catastrophic conditions in NSW yesterday.

The worst fires were in the south of the state, near Cooma, Nowra, Bega and Wagga Wagga.

The Rural Fire Service was last night reporting a home has been lost at Jugiong, north east of Gundagai.

A spokeswoman for the RFS said 20 more homes in the area were under threat. Sydney recorded a peak temperature of 42.5 degrees, with the heat set to remain as high as 30C overnight and into Wednesday morning.

RFS Commissioner Shane Fitzsimmons said firefighters had been ``very fortunate'' in the face of ``dirty, hot difficult conditions''.

More than 1600 firefighters were in the field or on standby last night, as temperatures climbed and fires fanned by winds of over 70km/h burned more than 60,000 hectares of grass, scrub and bushland. Thirty homes were threatened 12km east of Cooma - another 20 in the Kybeyan Valley and 10 in the Cooma-Monaro area.

RFS Riverina spokesman Matt Apps said firefighters were aiming to shore up their containment lines last night, particularly at Tarcutta, in southwest NSW, and at the Wokolena grass fire.

He said RFS crews were also keeping a close watch on a southerly wind change.

``The wind change makes it unpredictable,'' Mr Apps said.

At Tarcutta, a bushfire burnt through 500ha and surrounded the town.

By early evening the Hume Highway had been reopened in both directions with the immediate threat passing.

However, RFS spokesman Brendan Doyle urged people to remain vigilant. ``If the southerly wind changes, that may push the fire back on to the town,'' Mr Doyle said.

Up to 90 per cent of NSW was in severe danger, with conditions officially described as catastrophic in the Illawarra, Shoalhaven, the Southern Ranges, the northern and eastern Riverina and southern parts of the lower Central West Plains.

Three youths were taken into police custody yesterday afternoon after a suspicious fire at Shalvey in Sydney's west. Firefighters contained the blaze, which affected about 10 hectares of bushland.

The Salvation Army has launched the Australian Disaster Relief Appeal in response to the bushfires in communities in NSW and other communities across Australia.

A NATION ON ALERT

NSW

FIREFIGHTERS were last night battling 135 blazes in 40-plus temperatures, with conditions listed as ``catastrophic''.

THE fires have destroyed 66,000ha, with 25 fires raging out of control.

ONE home destroyed by fire at Jugiong, near Gundagai, the Rural Fire Service reported.

THE WORST fires were in the state's south near Cooma, Nowra, Bega and Wagga Wagga.

A FIRE in a transformer station of the Lucas Heights nuclear power station was contained by firefighters.

TASMANIA

ABOUT 40 bushfires still burning across the state, with uncontrolled blazes at Montumana in the northwest and at Lake Repulse in the Derwent Valley.

RESIDENTS told to evacuate areas on the Tasman Peninsula.

THE NUMBER of properties lost was confirmed at 128.

A 22,000ha bushfire burning out of control between Forcett and the Tasman Peninsula in southern Tasmania.

VICTORIA

A FIRE burning in Victoria's west, near Ballarat, destroyed at least two homes in Cheptsowe and firefighters reported it was burning out of control last night.

A SLOW-MOVING bushfire has burnt about 9000ha near the SA border and was last night threatening the Victorian town of Dartmoor.

SA

A STRING of fires were burning across the Far North but were not threatening property.

ACT

A FOREST fire is burning in the ACT's south, close to Mount Ginini in the western region of Namadgi National Park, but is under control.

QUEENSLAND

EIGHT bushfires burning under control across Queensland but none threatening property.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>WA: Emergency Services Minister confirms fires under control</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">PERTH, Jan 1 AAP - Emergency Services Minister Kevin Prince warned that a wild bushfire in the Perth hills region could flare up again.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Mr Prince confirmed the Glen Forest fire had been brought under control this afternoon by more than 200 fire fighting personnel.</p><p>"But of course with such hot weather at the moment there is every possibility it could flare up again," Mr Prince said.</p><p> "Fire crews will remain on hand for the next few days dampening things down and putting out any smouldering areas to make sure it is well and truly over."</p><p> He said although 200 hectares of land and a home had been destroyed, hundreds more residents in the popular foothills area were spared due to a wind change.</p><p> "There was a very real threat that more homes could have been lost, but by sheer luck the wind changed and the homes escaped any damage," he said.</p><p> Mr Prince praised the tireless work of the firefighters, some of whom have worked for more than 24 hours straight.</p><p> "It has been an extraordinary effort that was very well co-ordinated and run and I think we can all be intensely proud of the efforts of everyone involved," he said.</p><p> Mr Prince said the cause of the fire was unclear.</p><p> "It might be related to power lines but at this stage we just don't know," he said.</p><p> "However, fires can get started by all sorts of causes and there is no evidence to suggest it was deliberately lit."</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source
