urn:contentItem:59NK-SPY1-JCBD-B0SF-00000-00Glib climate remarks unwise2013-10-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisAPg. B008Glib climate remarks unwiseThe Canberra Times

Glib climate remarks unwise T ony Abbott showed this week he has lost none of his partiality for the pithy, cut- through phrases he employed so effectively during his years as opposition leader. Quizzed on radio about the link between climate change and the NSW bushfires, and informed of comments to that effect by the head of UN climate change negotiations, Christiana Figueres, the Prime Minister said the "official concerned [was] talking through her hat". A similar question from a tabloid columnist elicited the even more cursory judgment: "complete hogwash". So it was perhaps apt that Mr Abbott's famous throwaway line about climate change (that the science behind it was "crap") should have been disinterred by a BBC reporter and directed at Environment Minister Greg Hunt during an interview about the government's climate change policy and the bushfires. Mr Hunt could not bring himself to adopt the same truculent tone as his leader, and instead revealed that he had "looked up Wikipedia to see what the rest of the world thought, and it opens with the fact that bushfires in Australia are frequently occurring events during the hotter months of the year". That a minister, with a plenitude of resources and information to hand on climate change, should admit to referring to the not-entirely-reliable Wikipedia was inadvisable, but his point was clear enough.

An unequivocal link between climate change and increased bushfire risk has not been established and, indeed, it appears Ms Figueres' comments were rather more nuanced than Mr Abbott's interrogators led him to believe. What she said was that while the World Meteorological Organisation had not "yet" established a direct link, "the science is telling us that there are increasing heatwaves in Asia, Europe and Australia, and that they will continue in their intensity and in their frequency".

Mr Abbott's assertion that fires [and floods] have occurred since the earliest days of European settlement, and that "we have had worse in the past than the ones we are currently experiencing" is plainly true - as is his comment that the record-setting temperatures of recent years prove nothing definitive beyond the fact that "the longer the period of time, the more possibility of extreme events". While the world's climate is constantly changing, meteorologists and climate scientists have demonstrated that the increases in average global temperatures, particularly in the past 50 years, have occurred at unusual speed, and have predicted that the pace of change will intensify as atmospheric carbon dioxide levels rise. Earlier this year, the Bureau of Meteorology told a Senate inquiry into extreme events that the seasonal Forest Fire Danger Index had increased significantly since the 1970s, and that the largest increases had occurred during spring and autumn. A historically dry continent anyway, Australia now experiences significantly reduced winter rainfall across the south-west of Western Australia and large parts of south-eastern Australia, just as climate scientists predicted. With those areas all now characterised by dry soils and lack of rain, all it takes to create an extreme fire hazard is low relative humidity and high winds.

That risk has always been there, as Mr Abbott reminds us, but because of population overflow into areas like the Dandenong Ranges and the Blue Mountains, bushfires are now far costlier in human and economic terms than was once the case. The environmental cost, of course, is incalculable. Mr Abbott may remain unconvinced that bushfire disasters are occurring more frequently now, but insurance actuaries who are recommending higher fire and flood premiums are under no illusions.

After his election as Liberal leader in 2009, Mr Abbott excused his notorious climate change remark as "a bit of hyperbole", and not his "considered position". However, the Prime Minister's comments of this week, together with his government's half-hearted commitment to reducing greenhouse gas emissions by just 5 per cent by 2020, are evidence of lingering scepticism.

It is always possible that natural climate variability has contributed to global warming. But climate scientists are overwhelmingly of the view that greenhouse gas levels in the atmosphere, caused by human activity, are to blame. It is therefore unwise of Mr Abbott to so breezily dismiss their concerns.

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>NSW: Aussie, NZ firefighters lend a helping hand in US</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:dateline>SYDNEY, Aug 26</nitf:dateline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">A team of 50 firefighters from Australia and New Zealand will tomorrow leave for the United States to bolster numbers during the northern bushfire season.</p><p nitf:lede="true">The group will include 16 firefighters from NSW, comprising members of the Rural Fire Service, State Forests, National Parks and Wildlife Service and the NSW Fire Brigade.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Australian firefighters have travelled to the US to help local firefighters in three of the past four years.</p><p>A selection of the NSW contingent today went through a training course to prepare them for North American conditions.</p><p>With bushfires becoming an almost annual occurrence in NSW, firefighter John Fisher said the group would use the knowledge gained in the US to its advantage during the Australian summer.</p><p>"As well as making a valuable and necessary contribution to controlling these North American wildfires, the experience our firefighters gain will probably be put directly to use on fires in NSW as soon as they return," Mr Fisher said.</p><p>Mr Fisher, from Coffs Harbour, is a team leader in the expedition.</p><p>Paul de Mar, chairman of the Australian Forest Fire Officers Group, has been on the trip the past two years and although he's not going this year, he is the group's coordinator.</p><p>Mr de Mar said North America was currently on high fire alert.</p><p>"The United States and Canada are now on the highest fire preparedness level," Mr de Mar said.</p><p>"That means that two or more geographic areas are experiencing incidents (fires) … firefighting resources are becoming scarce and more unfavourable weather conditions are expected."</p><p>The Australians are expected to be there for at least three weeks.</p><p>In the past week, bushfires have burned out hundreds of thousands of hectares in western Canada and the US states of Oregon, Montana and Wyoming. More than 200 homes were destroyed in the western Canadian city of Kelowna and thousands of people were evacuated from the surrounding area.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW2003</dc:source><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-02-28</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="323"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 2003 Australian Associated Press Pty. urn:contentItem:4P0W-WS50-TXN5-V35F-00000-00Residents get wise to dangers, with blaze prevention advice2003-09-01T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 5Residents get wise to dangers, with blaze prevention adviceDANIELLE WOOLAGE

AS bushfires burned on the South Coast, residents across the Illawarra and Sutherland headed to Darkes Forest Rural Fire Station.

Fearing a summer similar to the one that brought the Black Christmas bushfires, they arrived at the bushfire awareness open day in droves on Saturday.

Most were unaware the bushfire season had already began. South Coast Rural Fire Service volunteers spent the weekend battling almost 20 blazes between Bega and Milton, most were contained yesterday.

Wollongong Fire Control planning and mitigation officer Michael Gray said Darkes Forest Rural Fire Service (RFS) volunteers were bombarded with questions about property protection and preparation during bushfires.

"There were questions about evacuation as well," Mr Gray said.

"This year the weather hasn't been favourable. We haven't had a lot of rain and obviously the drought is still continuing, especially out west. The longer we go without rain the worse it (the fire season) will be."

Mr Gray said the official start to the season was traditionally October 1.

"The danger period, as we call it, is from October 1 to March 31," he said.

But dry weather and strong winds brought early bushfires to the South Coast at the weekend and Mr Gray reminded people to prepare their property for bushfires.

"Remove dead vegetation and leaves from gutters and any flammables from sheds," he said.

"Families should also have a fire plan so if there is a bushfire they know what they have to do in an emergency."

Three Illus: Preparation: (Clockwise from top) An Otford Rural Fire Service officer puts on a display at Darkes Forest fire station. Volunteer Cassey James shows brothers Nathan and Anthony Fredericks how to use a fire hose. Rural firefighter Tim Crawford with his sons Lachlan, 18 months, and Nicholas, 4. Pictures: WAYNE VENABLES

urn:contentItem:3S8H-CD40-0048-T2TN-00000-00<published>1998-03-21T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:49:04Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: HUNDREDS OF FIRES RAGE IN INDONESIAN PROVINCE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Kieron Flynn</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true"> BONTANG, Indonesia, March 20 AFP - Hundreds of fires were razing great swathes of Indonesia's vast East Kalimantan province today, blanketing the region with smoke and threatening villages and key roads.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Up to 1,000 fires were raging and the situation was set to dramatically deteriorate as a prolonged drought drags on, firefighters and officials said.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Dozens of fires were deliberately lit by farmers and plantation and timber firms, sending sparks and hot ash across the province's rugged jungle and forest canopy to start fresh blazes elsewhere, they added.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> "It is much worse than last year and it is getting even worse," said Hartmut Abberger, of the German-funded Integrated Forest Fire Management Project in the provincial capital of Samarinda.</p><p>"When anyone starts a fire now, it is almost impossible to control," he added, saying his organisation's latest data gathered from satellite images showed more than 800 fires were burning in the province on the island of Borneo.</p><p> A government forestry official here, who declined to be named, said the situation was "hopeless" and that official figures showed up to 1,000 fires burning, ranging from small outbreaks to blazes</p><p> There were believed to be other fires in remote inland areas but access was difficult and communication links almost non-existent, he said.</p><p> "The government is doing its best but these farmers and the companies still start fires," he added.</p><p> Fires continued to burn in the Bukit Suharto forest area some 70 kilometres south of here today, where up to 3,000 hectares was razed over the past two weeks, officials said.</p><p> Scores of fires were also raging in the Kutai national park, some 80 kilometres north of Samarinda, with most of the blazes concentrated around the area's sole major road. Officials said this indicated they had been deliberately lit.</p><p> Residents of Bontang, the main town in the Kutai area, carried on their lives as normal as smoke spread over their homes and motorcyslists donned masks to filter out the smog.</p><p> A young orangutan appeared on the main road, the hair on its back blackened, but fled when approached by people.</p><p> The fires have forced thousands of animals from their home in the dense Borneo jungle and residents said the orangutans were increasingly seeking food in the villages.</p><p> "We see them all the time now, but they are a problem because they steal our food," a police officer in Bontang said.</p><p> The East Kalimantan fires are now spread over some 200 square kilometres, sending haze across the province, reducing visibility and blocking out the sun.</p><p> Fires around the small town of Tenggarong, some 40 kilometres up the Mahakam river from Samarinda, forced traffic to slow amid thick smoke and residents said crops already parched by the drought had been reduced to cinders.</p><p> The key road between Samarinda and Balikpapan, a booming oil city some 125 kilometres to the south, was choked with smoke in parts late today, with bitumen melting away at the edges of the two-lane highway.</p><p> Cloud-seeding efforts by authorities in recent weeks failed because of wind movements and officials are now pinning their hopes on a concerted campaign against blazes in Kutai.</p><p> The United Nations Development Program, Integrated Forest Fire Management Project and other non-governmental organisations plan to next week begin a short intensive training course for a 1,000-strong combined force of troops and civilians to check those fires.</p><p> While water tanks and hand tools could be used to tackle the blazes near the road, Abberger said those deeper into the forest would be difficult to deal with.</p><p> "They will have to hike three kilometres or so from the nearest road, so they will be exhausted when they arrive there," he said.</p><p> "The only equipment they will have will be what they can carry," he said, adding helicopters could not land in fire-stricken areas because of the smoke.</p><p> Fires in Kalimantan and on the Indonesian island of Sumatra last year sent choking haze across a large section of South-East Asia, causing widespread health problems and massive transport disruptions.</p><p> An international standard fire danger index, which rates risk from 0 to 2,000, has been at 2,000 for most of this week in East Kalimantan.</p><p>AFP cdh</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:3S8X-CB30-0048-T4SK-00000-00<published>1998-03-22T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:49:04Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Overseas News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: SMOKE SHROUDS INDONESIA'S EASTERN BORNEO AS FIRES RAGE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Kieron Flynn</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">BALIKPAPAN, Indonesia, March 22 AFP - Smoke blanketed the eastern coast of rugged Borneo island today as hundreds of fires raged across Indonesia's East Kalimantan province.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> The sun was invisible as dawn broke over the region, one of the world's last great wilderness areas, while troops and civilians again frantically tried to halt the advance of the fires.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Soldiers wielding hoes and shovels were attempting to dig firebreaks around the main 125km highway between the cities of Balikpapan and Samarinda as the bitumen melted around them.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Villagers were also on roads north and south of the oil boom-town of Balikpapan, carrying buckets of water from nearby creeks and rivers with levels already shrunken by a months-long drought.</p><p>"I don't know if it will help. I am just doing what my husband tells me," said Ibu (Ms) Ari, a farming woman on the highway south of Balikpapan.</p><p> "Every year there are fires but now they seem to continue. They can't be stopped."</p><p> Fires are now spread over some 200 square kilometres, sending haze across the province and blocking out the sun. They have raised fears of a repeat of last autumn's haze that blanketed much of Southeast Asia, causing a major health hazard.</p><p> Firefighters say the drought, exaggerated by the El Nino weather pattern, has left Borneo's forests tinder-dry and that fires started by plantation and timber companies and traditional slash-and-burn farmers are razing the once virgin forest.</p><p> "Our orders are to stop the fire," added one of the soldiers on the same road.</p><p> Visibility in Balikpapan was reduced to just a few hundred metres and fresh blazes - mostly to the west and southwest of Balikpapan, some within 10km of the city - were razing forests and bushland. But villagers protected their homes by pouring water onto the dust which surrounds the settlements.</p><p> Residents and officials here said the fires were believed to have been deliberately lit by farmers to clear land but had got out of control in the hot and dry conditions amid a prolonged drought.</p><p> Soldiers worked on major highways, batting down the roadside flames with rakes and shovels while the infernos spread inland.</p><p> "I don't know who started it but my fields are finished," said one elderly woman villager on the southwestern outskirts of Balikapapan.</p><p> Large fires also raged in the Bukit Suharto (Suharto Hill) forest area 40km north of here. Some 3,000 hectares had been razed there over the past two weeks after a farmer lit a fire to clear land for a new peppercorn field, firefighters said.</p><p> Scores of fires were also burning in Kutai national park, 80km north of Samarinda, with most of the blazes concentrated around the area's sole major road. Officials said this indicated they had been deliberately lit.</p><p> Up to 1,000 fires, deliberately lit by farmers and plantation and timber firms, are sending sparks and hot ash across the province's rugged jungle and forest canopy to start fresh blazes elsewhere, firefighters and officials said.</p><p> "It is much worse than last year and it is getting even worse," said Hartmut Abberger, of the German-funded Integrated Forest Fire Management Project in Samarinda. "When anyone starts a fire now, it is almost impossible to control."</p><p> Cloud-seeding efforts by authorities in recent weeks failed because of wind movements. Officials are now pinning their hopes on a concerted campaign in Kutai.</p><p> The United Nations Development Program, Integrated Forest Fire Management Project and other non-governmental organisations plan to begin a short intensive training course for a 1,000-strong combined force of troops and civilians.</p><p> The fires also threaten the province's dwindling orangutan population and a rare dolphin species unique to the area, environmentalists warned.</p><p> The drought and fire have reduced the flow of fresh water in the Mahakam river and its tributaries, lowering their levels and endangering some 200 freshwater dolphins.</p><p>AFP shb</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1998</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3S8X-CB30-0048-T4SK-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-23</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="664"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1998 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4P89-SK80-TXN5-V1VX-00000-00NSW fire experts on offer to Asia1997-09-26T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisNEWSPg. 19NSW fire experts on offer to Asia

The NSW Government has offered to send firefighters to Indonesia to help battle forest fires that had created a smog crisis in the region.

Emergency Services Minister Bob Debus said he had written to the Australian Ambassador in Indonesia informing him that the NSW Rural Fire Service was ready to help fight the fires.

"It is not an overstatement to claim that the NSW Rural Fire Service is a world leader in rural and forest fire suppression and management," Mr Debus said.

"Their outstanding effort during the January 1994 bushfires stands as clear testimony to their expertise."

He said NSW firefighters already had helped Indonesian authorities twice before, in 1991 and 1994.

Indonesia has been criticised by Malaysia and Singapore because smoke from forest fires in Borneo and Sumatra has cast a pall over those two countries for months and sent air pollution indexes to unhealthy levels.

The Federal Government has warned Australians with respiratory or heart conditions and pregnant women to consider deferring plans to travel to some smoke-choked regions of South-East Asia.

Australian residents in Brunei and Malaysia, where the haze has polluted the air for months, are using up outstanding holiday leave in order to move their families to cleaner air, according to reports from Australian commissions in the region.

The High Commission in Kuala Lumpur was receiving about 25 calls a day from Australians worried about the health effects of the smoke, a spokeswoman said.

Illus: MR DEBUS

xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>ASIA: HUNDREDS OF FIRES RAGE IN INDONESIAN PROVINCE</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline><nitf:byline>By Kieron Flynn</nitf:byline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">BALIKPAPAN, Indonesia, March 21 AFP - Hundreds of fires blanketed swathes of Indonesia's East Kalimantan province with choking smoke torday, leaving a trail of devastation in their wake amid warnings the situation is set to worsen.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Fresh blazes broke out as orangutans fled the fires and fauna was endangered, environmentalists said.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Visibility in the major coastal oil city of Balikpapan was reduced to just a few hundred metres, disrupting some flights, airport officials said, adding the runway remained open.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Pedestrians and motorcyclists donned masks as the smoke thickened in the city, some 125 kilometres south of the provincial capital of Samarinda, while new fires erupted around it.</p><p>The air cleared in the afternoon as winds swept in a cycle residents said is repeated almost daily.</p><p> Soldiers worked on major highways, batting down the roadside flames with rakes and shovels while the infernos spread inland.</p><p> The fresh blazes  mostly to the west and south-west of<br/>Balikpapan, some within 10 kilometres of the city  razed forests<br/> and bushland.</p><p> Residents and officials here said the fires were believed to have been deliberately lit by farmers, plantation and timber companies, but had gotten out of control in the hot and dry conditions amid a prolonged drought.</p><p> "I don't know who started it but my fields are kaput," said one elderly woman villager on the southwestern outskirts of Balikapapan.</p><p> Large fires also raged in the Bukit Suharto forest area, some 40 kilometres north of here, with flames licking at the main highway linking Balikpapan and Samarinda.</p><p> Some 3,000 hectares were razed in Bukit Suharto, or Suharto Hill, over the past two weeks after a farmer lit a fire to clear land for a new peppercorn field, firefighters said.</p><p> Scores of fires were also burning in Kutai national park, 80 kilometres north of Samarinda, with most of the blazes concentrated around the area's sole major road. Officials said this indicated they had been deliberately lit.</p><p> Up to 1,000 fires were blazing yesterday and the situation was set to deteriorate as the drought drags on, firefighters and officials said.</p><p> Dozens of fires are sending sparks and hot ash across the province's rugged jungle and forest canopy to start fresh blazes elsewhere, they added.</p><p> "It is much worse than last year and it is getting even worse," said Hartmut Abberger, of the German-funded Integrated Forest Fire Management Project in Samarinda.</p><p> Fires in Borneo island are now spread over some 200 square kilometres, sending haze across the province, reducing visibility and blocking out the sun.</p><p> Cloud-seeding efforts by authorities in recent weeks failed because of wind movements. Officials are now pinning their hopes on a concerted campaign in Kutai.</p><p> The United Nations Development Program, Integrated Forest Fire Management Project and other non-governmental organisations plan to begin next week a short intensive training course for a 1,000-strong combined force of troops and civilians to check those fires.</p><p> The fires also threaten the province's dwindling orangutan population and a rare dolphin species unique to the area, environmentalists warned.</p><p> The drought and fire have reduced the flow of fresh water in the Mahakam river and its tributaries, lowering their levels and endangering the some 200 freshwater dolphins.</p><p> "They are now in danger and we think they have gone further up the rivers looking for more fresh water," said Ketut Deddy Muliastra, the World Wide Fund for Nature (WWF) representative in the provincial capital of Samarinda.</p><p> "There is nowhere else for them to go, but there is no more water up the rivers either."</p><p> Orangutans, driven from their natural habitat around the Kutai national park, have increasingly been seen on the sole main road which runs through the area and are entering villages in search of food, environmentalists and residents said.</p><p> Muliastra said one area of forest where 126 bird species had previously been recorded was now home to a fraction of that number as they fled to safer areas.</p><p> Fires in Kalimantan and on the Indonesian island of Sumatra last year sent choking haze across a large section of Southeast Asia, causing widespread health problems and massive transport disruptions.</p><p>AFP cdh</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source urn:contentItem:4GNT-J9K0-015G-P1WB-00000-00<published>2005-07-21T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:49:04Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>WORLD; Pg. 9</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>Firefighter describes killer 'wave' of flame</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MADRID: A Spanish firefighter who saw 11 colleagues die battling a forest fire has told how they were overtaken by a "giant wave" of flame heading towards them at furious speed.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Jesus Abad, the only survivor of 12 firefighters trapped on Sunday in a remote area of Guadalajara province, 150km east of Madrid, escaped with burned arms and broken ribs by sheltering under a water truck that had water pouring out of it, his wife told El Pais newspaper.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Mr Abad told Spanish television: "The hurricane of fire was very big. I think it saw us and said, 'You're mine', because it came from a very long way off.</p><section sectionType="source"><bodyText><p>Reuters</p></bodyText></section><p>"The next time we turned our heads, the flames were leaping out at us and we got in the vehicles to get away … but it didn't give us time and it caught us, as if it were a giant wave, but of fire."</p><p>Blinded by smoke, Mr Abad said he had driven into a gully. He jumped out of a window and crawled under a water truck that was standing on the road.</p><p>After the fire passed he saw that his companions had all burned to death. Mr Abad was rescued by a helicopter and is now recovering in hospital.</p><p>"You have no oxygen, you see yourself burning, you see yourself … dead," he said. "The will to live saved me, because I think we all have courage."</p><p>The fire scorched up to 13,000ha of forest and brush. By yesterday it was contained and close to being brought under control thanks to an 80m fire break, officials said.</p><p>Police were questioning a group of daytrippers who told them they had lit a barbecue on Saturday in the area, which had been turned into a tinder box by Spain's worst drought since the 1940s.</p><p>Causing a fatal fire can be punished in Spain with 20 years in jail.</p><p>Spain has about 20,000 forest fires a year, 90 per cent of which are started by humans.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:4G7W-5170-015G-T41K-00000-00<published>2005-05-26T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:49:04Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>LETTERS; Pg. 16</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>So it's shift, boys, shift …</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">THE Victorian Government is to be commended for placing the public environmental interest first in finally bringing an end to licensed cattle-grazing in the Alpine National Park.</p><p nitf:lede="true">This belatedly brings Victoria's alpine park management into line with established practice in NSW and the ACT.</p><p nitf:lede="true">Particular commendation is due for the Government's decision to recognise that not only has cattle grazing caused excessive damage, but that its remediation requires dedicated additional funding, rather than simply imposing additional stress on Parks Victoria's budget.</p><p>Steve Douglas, School of Resources, Environment and Society, ANU</p><p>I HAVE rarely seen a more misleading advertisement than the State Government's "A New Beginning for the Alpine National Park" (May 25). A photograph, "It's for people", shows the beautiful high country stretching away to its mountainous horizons.</p><p>Maybe the little pool with the cattle in the other photograph is tucked away somewhere in the scene.</p><p> If this is the outcome of pre-settlement firing followed by more than 150 years of cattle grazing, then the result can only be described as brilliant.</p><p> Enjoy it while you can.</p><p> Without the grazing and with the well-proven mismanagement of Parks Victoria, the open flowery heath will be soon invaded by scrub and noxious weeds and plagued by delayed, devastating high-intensity fires.</p><p> Colin M. Barton, Glen Waverley</p><p> CONGRATULATIONS to the Victorian Government for ending alpine grazing.</p><p>The outcome is fair, with graziers receiving compensation and the national parks being able to recover from the damage of grazing and recent bushfires. I look forward to bushwalking without treading in cow pats.</p><p> Ian Harwood, Southbank</p><p>ABOUT 8000 cattle eating 10kg of vegetable matter each day for 16 weeks a year equals almost 9000 tonnes of forest floor fuel removed from the fire equation.</p><p>Removing that much fuel means that native fauna may have a chance of survival in the case of forest fire.</p><p>Mr Bracks has just sentenced these cute animals to a high-temperature death.</p><p>John Cribbes, Sale</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:4S54-MM70-TX5N-00S4-00000-00Don't just blame the droughts2008-03-28T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisPg. 7Don't just blame the droughtsKAROLIN MacGREGOR

DROUGHT is often blamed for the Midlands tree decline. Now landowners have been told several others factors are involved.

Last week, about 20 landowners and industry authorities gathered for a tree-decline workshop at Oatlands.

Neil Davidson, from the University of Tasmania, has been involved in research into tree decline for about two decades. He also heads the latest Addressing Tree Decline project.

Mr Davidson said that in the past 20 years there had been significant developments in understanding the causes of tree decline.

Although there had been much focus on contributing factors, such as possums, insects and dry conditions, now the importance of creating a more natural growing environment for trees was becoming clear.

Mr Davidson said farming practices such as grazing, establishing perennial pastures and fertilising were now recognised as the major causes of tree losses in the Midlands region.

To re-establish healthy forests and preserve existing ones, Mr Davidson said, it was necessary to provide protection from grazing and to create a more natural system that included understorey species and old fallen logs.

``There is not one single factor that is causing the losses of these trees; it's a combination,'' he said.

``Trees have enormous resilience in a natural system if they don't have extra stresses applied through normal farming practices.''

In a natural forest, fire played an important role by promoting germination of seeds and providing vital nutrients for new seedlings.

Old fallen logs, he said, also provided protection for seedlings from wind and helped retain moisture.

A new project, Addressing Tree Decline is now under way.

Funded by Natural Resource Management South, the project is evaluating methods of re-establishing natural forest conditions.

The trial will involve a variety of forest species and be carried out at eight sites in areas including Oatlands, Swansea, Bothwell, Dunalley and Lemont. Each site will be 100m wide and 200m long.

The sites will be fenced.

Half will be treated, while the other half will remain untouched as controls.

Mr Davidson said the trial would focus on several 5x5m segments in each forest and use methods such as cultivation, fire and bringing in woody material in an effort to re-establish ideal forest-growing conditions.

The effects of these methods would then be evaluated over several years.

During last week's workshop, landowners were asked to think about how these re-establishment methods could be applied on a larger scale on farms.

urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4PX0-0048-T4KX-00000-00<published>1997-09-25T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:49:04Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>Nationwide General News; Australian General News</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>VIC: VIC FIREFIGHTERS UNLIKELY TO GO TO INDONESIA</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">MELBOURNE, Sept 25 AAP - Victorian firefighters, faced with the prospect of serious bushfires this summer, were unlikely to be spared to help combat the Indonesian bushfires that have created a smog crisis in the region.</p><p nitf:lede="true"> Firefighting forces said today they had not been approached and needed to keep their resources at home to counter any early fire outbreaks after unseasonally dry weather.</p><p>United Firefighters Union Victorian branch secretary Peter Marshall said last night Australia was likely to join Japan and France in offering expertise and other help to fight the fires.</p><p> But Metropolitan Fire Brigade (MFB) board president Brian Parry said there had been no request to the brigade or talks with the federal government.</p><p> "I am absolutely mystified as to what this is all about. We haven't been asked and we are trained for urban firefighting and we are not particularly into forest fire fighting," Mr Parry said.</p><p> Mr Marshall also said the MFB would continue to hold talks with the federal government in response to a plea to the government for help from a Malaysian crisis committee.</p><p> However MFB emergency response director, assistant chief fire officer Keith Adamson said the brigade was building up to a serious fire season and needed to maximise its equipment and personnel here, not send any overseas.</p><p> The Country Fire Authority and the National Resources and Environment Department's fire fighting section both said they had not been approached to help.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:source sourceScheme="royaltyReportingKey">AAPNEW1997</dc:source><dc:identifier identifierScheme="PGUID">urn:contentItem:3SJJ-4PX0-0048-T4KX-00000-00</dc:identifier><dc:source sourceScheme="productContentSetIdentifier">160586</dc:source><dc:date dateType="last-updated">2016-01-24</dc:date></dc:metadata><wordCount number="249"/><publicationInfo><publicationName>AAP NEWSFEED</publicationName><copyright>Copyright 1997 AAP Information Services Pty. urn:contentItem:4MBT-Y000-TX4S-M2W4-00000-00TO THE POINT2006-11-16T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisAPg. 20TO THE POINTThe Canberra Times

GAME HUNT SHAMEFUL Rumpole where are you, with your golden thread of justice - the presumption of innocence?

First Brogden, now Orkopoulos.

Have the members of the Bear Pit no shame or collective memory?

Of course not, anything and anyone, sleazebag or not, is fair game in the pursuit of electoral victory. P L Morrall, Kambah RUMBLES OF DEMURRAL Congratulations to Sydney University for being selected to host the prestigious US Studies Centre. I can hear the howls of protest already from the "long marcher", lefty US-phobic academics.

Tom Ruut, Garran WHAT'S IN A NAME?

John Thistleton's story ("Awarded design invigorates John Curtin Research School", November 13, p5) noted that project director Medi Hassan, John Hindmarsh, and John Curtin chief professor Judith Whitworth are proud of the new research school building.

What a shame that the architect responsible for the "invigorating design", Carey Lyon, was not mentioned.

Enrico Taglietti, Griffith CREATIVE INTERPRETATION A little knowledge is a dangerous thing, as shown by Vic Adams (Letters, November 14) when arguing that the Australian Bureau of Statistics says that interest rates of 17.3 per cent under the last Labor government were less than under the Coalition government that preceded it. His view can only be sustained through a selective and creative interpretation of data.

In essence, Adams is wrong.

Richard Humphies, Lawson Farm, Cooma, NSW PLAY INTO THEIR HANDS Tony Blair's claim that tougher security measures are needed to defeat terrorism is strange, given that he chose a different path in solving the problem of Northern Irish terrorism. The idea that the current wave of terrorism by extremist Islamic organisations is something new and frighteningly different simply plays into the hands of those people.

Peter Marshall, Captains Flat, NSW INEVITABLE DELAYED The coalition of the witless continues to pour oil on the forest fire it has created in Iraq.

Bush, Blair and Howard declare that they will not "cut and run".

Staying in Iraq to prop up a government of no-hopers merely delays the inevitable scramble to get out and increases the tallies of dead.

M H MacKenzie-Orr, Hughes THE ALTERNATE WORD John Woodrow bemoans the use of "alternate" and wonders where "alternative" went (Letters, November 15). It's simple, mate.

It's 'cos they're "igrant".

Malcolm Gerloch, Melba

xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo><sourceSectionInfo><positionSection>PULSE; Pg. 19</positionSection></sourceSectionInfo></itemInfo></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>LLOYD STAYS IN COMMOTION</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">LLOYD Cole hit big when he delivered Rattlesnakes as his first album back in 1984.</p><p nitf:lede="true">He had joined forces with ace backing outfit The Commotions in 1983 and developed the bunch of songs that made up his impressive debut, including Perfect Skin, Heartbroken, Forest Fire and the uplifting title track, over the next year.</p><p>That release pioneered a new kind of intellectual British pop, a welcome relief from the synthesised plod of the New Romantics.</p><p>Easy Pieces (1985) was the solid follow-up, which included another instant classic in the superb single, Brand New Friend.</p><p>Cole opted to split the Commotions after a disappointing third album, Mainstream, and chose a more obscure route as a solo artist, maintaining a cult following but never recapturing the burst of commercial success prompted by Rattlesnakes.</p><p>Yet the British singer/songwriter has continued to challenge himself, working with friends and branching into new fields.</p><p>He asked singer/songwriter Matthew Sweet to play on his self-titled 1990 release, and returned the favor on Sweet's acclaimed Girlfriend.</p><p>He also employed former Lou Reed guitarist Robert Quine and drummer Fred Maher for that album and turned to arranger Paul Buckmaster (Elton John, Rolling Stones) for Don't Get Weird on Me Babe (1991), which ventured into cabaret music.</p><p>Along the way, Cole has produced New York band Ivy's Apartment Life, recorded Chelsea Hotel for the 1996 Leonard Cohen tribute I'm Your Fan, and contributed songs to the There's Something About Mary soundtrack.</p><p>While some solo releases have been greeted with indifference, 1995's Love Story was regarded as a return to form, and marked a reteaming with Commotions guitarist Neil Clark.</p><p>See Lloyd Cole at the Governor Hindmarsh this Friday, November 24.</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata xmlns:dc="http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/"><dc:identifier urn:contentItem:49ND-Y7Y0-01S8-D1V5-00000-00<published>1992-10-01T00:00:00Z</published><updated>2025-11-15T08:49:04Z</updated><author><name>LexisNexis</name></author><content type="application/xml"><!--Transformation version 1.25--><articleDoc xmlns="" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:noNamespaceSchemaLocation="http://www.lexisnexis.com/xmlschemas/content/public/articledoc/1/" schemaVersion="1.8" xml:lang="en"><articleDocHead><itemInfo/></articleDocHead><nitf:body xmlns:nitf="http://iptc.org/std/NITF/2006-10-18/"><nitf:body.head><nitf:hedline><nitf:hl1>BRIEFLY</nitf:hl1></nitf:hedline></nitf:body.head><nitf:body.content><bodyText><p nitf:lede="true">Camps taken COLOMBO - Government troops captured three Tamil rebel camps within a few hours of launching an offensive in north-western Sri Lanka. A military official said one soldier was killed and four were wounded.</p><p>At least 20 rebels were said to have been killed or wounded.</p><p> Election hit LUANDA - Gunmen shot dead a policeman guarding the house of the deputy Minister of the Interior today in the first violent incident of Angola's elections, police said.</p><p> Forest blaze SACRAMENTO - Seven hundred firefighters battled today to control a forest fire that has destroyed 3700 ha of Californian forest and destroyed 40 buildings.</p><p> JFK move WASHINGTON - The US Congress today sent President Bush legislation to make public virtually all of the Government's classified files on the assassination of President John F. Kennedy.</p><p> Vote tip PRAGUE - Fewer than 40 per cent of Czechs and Slovaks would vote for the break-up of Czechoslovakia if a referendum were held on the issue, according to a government poll.</p><p> And finally . . .</p><p>NEW YORK - Maria Ramos, 30, and Darryl Washington, 32, were making love on the track bed of the Bowery subway station in lower Manhattan when a train came in. Ms Ramos was bruised and scratched. Mr Washington suffered severed toes, a broken thigh, a small spinal fracture and cuts.</p><p> END OF STORY</p></bodyText></nitf:body.content></nitf:body><metadata><dc:metadata urn:contentItem:5PDX-RV81-F0JP-W28P-00000-00THE FINALS COUNTDOWN2017-09-08T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisSPORTPg. 85THE FINALS COUNTDOWNMIKEY CAHILL

KEEN beans would have noticed Saturday night games this season featured AFL players' song selections in and out of the ad breaks. Hit reporter MIKEY CAHILL ranks the AFL finals players' pump-up jams from 20 to 1.

20 JACK RIEWOLDT Richmond My Friends - Kayex.

Combining ZHU's Faded with Rufus' You Were Right to make something not as good as either. This plodder is the exact opposite to the way the Tigers spearhead attacks the footy.

Best bit: The "drop" gets a B minus.

Key lyric: "Just call on me my friend." Sorry, wrong number, kthxbai.

19 CHARLIE CAMERON Adelaide Sexual featuring Dyo - Neikid.

Atrocious Flume-lite build-up, insufferable faux-emotional vocals from Dyo (shoulda got Dido). As sexy as week-old celery. Come on Chuck.

Best bit: When it ends.

Key lyric: "You are, you are, you are ..." Spit it out, love.

18 HEATH SHAW GWS Kiss From a Rose - Seal.

We can all agree this is an amazing ballad. But does Shaw really crank this up in the headphones to get him in the zone? Baffling.

Best bit: Thinking about Heidi Klum.

Key lyric: "My power, my pleasure, my pain."

17 TOBY GREENE GWS Moments - Bliss n Eso.

Middling 'Strayan skip-hop. Worth booing whenever it comes on. That's exactly the wrong thing to do to Greene according to teammate Tom Scully. "Toby thrives off that stuff." Don't poke the bear.

Best bit: The hook. And Greene knows a thing or two about the right hook. Key lyric: "The first time I heard Pac, the first time it's all new."

16 LUKE SHUEY West Coast Something Like This - The Chainsmokers and Coldplay.

Not Clocks? Not Yellow? Not Viva La Vida? Not the bloody Chainsmokers. Best bit: The YouTube ads before the song starts.

Key lyric: "Doo-doo-doo-doo." As in do-do like Americans mean it.

15 KANE LAMBERT Richmond Californication - Red Hot Chili Peppers.

Classic song, but, mind on the job, Kane.

Best bit: When Jon Frusciante takes his guitar for a little walk. Key lyric: "Cobain can you hear the spheres, Singing songs off station to station."

14 LEWIS JETTA West Coast Sexual Healing - Marvin Gaye.

As above.

Best bit: That first "Baaaaaaby". Puts the spectacular in speccie. Key lyric: "Baby, I'm hot just like an oven, I need some lovin'."

13 SAM MENEGOLA Geelong I Need a Forest Fire James Blake featuring Bon Iver.

The most intellectual choice from the lad who grew up in East Fremantle. A mature selection from a "mature-age" player. Whatever fires you up.

Best bit: The seamless intermingling of voices, exactly what the Cats are hoping for on the field.

Key lyric: "Caution, swelling, can I repay you with some blame."

12 SHANNON HURN West Coast Sweet Child o' Mine - Guns 'n' Roses. The whole of Appetite For Destruction is prime pump-up material. Turn this up to 11 and feel invincible, Hurn Dog.

Best bit: Every note Slash slashes out.

Key lyric: "Where do we go now? Where do we go?" Answer: Forward.

11 SHANE EDWARDS Richmond If I Had a Tail - Queens of the Stone Age.

This is a barnburner. Edwards will want to become his spirit creature (a Tiger, we presume) and rip the opposition apart with some ferocious tackling.

Best bit: Josh Homme's post-coital "ahhh hooo".

Key lyric: "Get your hands dirty, roll up them sleeves." You heard the man!

10 CLAUDE THE CROW Adelaide Shake It Off - Taylor Swift Ahhh yes, you remember the "old Taylor". Claude is a sworn enemy of Hawka after the Hawthorn mascot embarrassed the dirty bird in a dance-off. But look who's playing finals and who is writing this sto â€¦ recuperating after a patchy year.

Best bit: The whole thing is perfect. And what you should do after copping a bump.

Key lyric: "Cause the players gonna play, play, play, play, play". All right, don't rub it in.

9 SHANE MUMFORD GWS Beds are Burning- Midnight Oil.

An absolute belter. So much intent. I'm gonna let it slide that Mummy also included Eiffel 65's Blue on his list.

Best bit: Those first horn stabs, then the swaggering rhythm section, then everything that follows.

Key lyric: "Steam in 45 degrees. "

8 ANTHONY McDONALD-TIPUNGWUTI Essendon Billie Jean - Michael Jackson I have it on good authority McDonald-Tipungwuti can cut a rug on the dancefloor. The youngster needs to be loose and relaxed before his first finals match and this will do the trick. Deadly.

Best bit: That undeniable bassline.

Key lyric: "Don't think twice (don't think twice)."

7 CHARLIE CAMERON Adelaide Lose Yourself- Eminem.

Look who's B. I. T (back in town). This is much more like it. Marshall Mathers' ode to fulfilling one's potential through the power of rap (and he was secretly dating Kim Basinger on the set of 8 Mile).

Fun fact:Lose Yourself was scientifically proven as the song that causes most car-crashes. Sort of what Cameron does to packs when he's at full pelt.

Best bit: The ominous guitars.

Key lyric: "You own it, you better never let it go, You only get one shot."

6 ZACH TUOHY Geelong Let It Go - Idina Menzel (Frozen).

Roight thar lads, yer man joost loooves a bit of Elsa hitting de roight notes 'cos it remoinds yer man of his sawn Flynn so who are weh ta joodge. Great craic.

Best bit: Reference to the cold not bothering Zach - he grew up playing Gaelic football for Portlaoise.

Key lyric: "Don't let them in, don't let them see." That is, deny opposition entry into their forward 50.

5 DARCY BYRNE-JONES Port Adelaide Drop The Game- Flume and Chet Faker.

A game-changer. Both Chet Faker (now Nick Murphy) and Flume have become premiership players for the music industry and kicked goals (sorry) playing by international rules. Byrne-Jones could be a game-changer if he gets a run.

Best bit: The heavy, loping beat.

Key lyric: "Hush, I said there's more to life than rush."

4 TOM PAPLEY Sydney Congratulations featuring Quavo - Post Malone.

The Bunyip boy is on the boil here. Jack Riewoldt you should be taking notes. Fun fact: Post Malone are playing FOMO by Night in Melbourne, January 11 at Festival Hall with Kaytranada.

Best bit: The truth bomb below.

Key lyric: "They said I wouldn't be nothing, Now they always say congratulations, Worked so hard, forgot how to vacation, They ain't never had the dedication."

3 NIC NEWMAN Sydney Believe - Cher (DMAs cover).

This song was chosen by Newman for the Pride match in Round 18. Shout out to Maverick, Newman's openly gay brother because it's a way I can muscle #VoteYES into the sports section of the Herald Sun.

Best bit: DMAs' heartfelt take on Cher's vocoder banger for Triple J's Like a Version. Brave move.

Key lyric: "I really don't think you're strong enough." Words Newman will whisper in Michael Hurley's ears.

2 DAVID ASTBURY Richmond Wolf Like Me - TV On The Radio.

If you're not familiar with this track rectify this now. Loudly. Best bit: The bit before it ramps up again and Astbury starts breaking the lines.

Key lyric: "My heart's aflame, My body's strained, but, God, I like it."

1 TOM STEWART Geelong Let It Happen - Tame Impala.

1 TOM STEWART Geelong Let It Happen - Tame Impala Excellent advice. Case in point: Roger Federer practises so much that he doesn't really think while he's playing. Stewart's impeccable song selection may lead to a similarly effortless BOG after he denies forwards such as Jack Riewoldt. Let it Happen is a mantra for finals players. Don't think, DO.

Best bit: When everything kicks back in at the 5min 12sec mark. Now that's a drop, Kayex.

Key lyric: "Let it happen, it's gonna feel so good" and "I will not vanish, you will not scare me".

Song list, courtesy Channel 7

urn:contentItem:51MB-HCF1-DYG0-922Y-00000-00Highlights of the AAP world wire at 19:00 Dec 32010-12-03T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisINTERNATIONAL NEWSHighlights of the AAP world wire at 19:00 Dec 3

  HIGHLIGHTS WORLD (ATTN EDITORS)
Highlights of the AAP world file since 15:00
NZ mine site 'challenging': Aussie expert
   WELLINGTON, Dec 3 NZPA/AAP - An Australian mine safety expert says New Zealand's Pike River mine site is the most challenging he has encountered, as work continues to make the mine safe enough to rescue the bodies of 29 men. (NZ MINE Wrap sent at 18:08, 447 words.)


Thousands battle to tame Israel fire
   HAIFA, Israel, Dec 3 AFP - Thousands of Israeli firemen and rescuers fought on Friday to control a massive forest fire that has already killed 41, as global help poured in to battle the biggest inferno in the country's history. (ISRAEL FIRE Wrap sent at 19:29, 721 words.)
Press blasts Israel's firefighters
   JERUSALEM, Dec 3 AFP - Israel's complete lack of readiness to handle a brutal fire ravaging huge swathes of forest near the northern city of Haifa, was on Friday blasted as catastrophic by the press. (ISRAEL FIRE MEDIA sent at 19:35, 387 words.)
12 dead as heavy snow, flooding hit Europe
   BERLIN, Dec 3 AP - Freezing temperatures and often blinding snowfall killed 12 more people and caused travel chaos across northern Europe, while some of the worst floods in a century devastated parts of the Balkans. (EUROPE WEATHER Update sent at 16:57, 780 words.) EDS: Reissuing to fix literal in second para (EUROPE WEATHER Update (Reissuing) sent at 17:08, 789 words.)
WikiLeaks dropped by domain name provider
   STOCKHOLM, Dec 3 AP - WikiLeaks' domain name system provider says it has withdrawn service to the wikileaks.org name. (WIKILEAKS DOMAIN sent at 19:04, 59 words.)
China blocks flights of artist, economist
   BEIJING, Dec 3 AP - China's crackdown before next week's Nobel Peace Prize presentation ceremony has widened to block a well-known artist and an economist who's more than 80 years old from travelling overseas. (CHINA NOBEL sent at 19:04, 473 words.)
Lockerbie bomber to sue over 'neglect'
   LONDON, Dec 3 PA - The family of the Lockerbie bomber is to sue over his "neglect" in a Scottish jail, Libyan leader Colonel Muammar Gaddafi has said. (UK LOCKERBIE sent at 19:01, 200 words.)
Saudi king to undergo more surgery in US
   RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, Dec 3 AFP - Saudi King Abdullah, 86, will undergo more surgery on his back in the United States on Friday, the royal court said, nine days after his first operation to fix a herniated disc. (SAUDI KING sent at 17:44, 473 words.)
Indonesia downgrades Merapi volcano alert
   YOGYAKARTA, Dec 3 AFP - Indonesian scientists have downgraded the alert status of Mount Merapi from the highest level after a series of violent eruptions that started in late October and killed more than 350 people. (INDON VOLCANO sent at 17:43, 281 words.)
Malaysia detains Indon terror suspect
   KUALA LUMPUR, Dec 3 AFP - Malaysia confirmed on Friday it has detained an Indonesian terrorist suspect linked to the Jemaah Islamiyah outfit, and will deport him as soon as possible. (TERROR MALAYSIA sent at 17:02, 282 words.)

urn:contentItem:4M3X-F670-TWT8-W2PV-00000-00Vic: Campers told to go as fire approaches2006-10-13T00:00:00Z2025-11-15T08:49:04ZLexisNexisDOMESTIC NEWSVic: Campers told to go as fire approachesXavier La Canna and Simon MossmanMELBOURNE Oct 13

  Campers have been urged to leave parts of Victoria's Barmah Forest as firefighters battle a huge blaze near the Murray River.
   Department of Sustainability and the Environment (DSE) state duty officer Alen Slijepcevic said the Barmah Forest fire had burned about 450 hectares by 7pm (AEST).


   About 30 campers were told to leave the area as the fire approached and the two main entrances to the forest, a popular weekend getaway, were closed.
   Mr Slijepcevic said 80 firefighters would be battling the fire throughout the night and hoped to have it contained by morning, with a wind change likely to help efforts.
   The fire was one of 35 being tackled tonight by the DSE, and Country Fire Authority (CFA) officers were called to 88 incidents during the day.
   Meanwhile, the CFA has warned a fire in the state's Latrobe Valley was expected to burn for days.
   The fire, at International Power's open cut brown coal mine at Hazelwood, near Morwell, stretched more than two kilometres along the western coalface and was being tackled by about 200 firefighters.
   CFA spokeswoman Jodie Guest said it was hoped favourable winds would mean it did not spread to another coalface at the mine.
   She said it would likely be another three to four days before the fire was brought under control.
   The mine feeds the Hazelwood Power Station, one of Victoria's largest power generators, which produces up to 25 per cent of Victoria's power.
   Another fire, at Faith Creek, in steep mountain country 12km north-west of Erica, was largely contained, with only 44 staff due to tackle the blaze overnight, down from 190 today, Mr Slijepcevic said.
   He said another fire, at Long Spur, near Noojee, would probably be contained by 10am tomorrow and had burned about 24 hectares.
   Another fire that had posed a headache for the CFA, at Yallourn North, near Moe, was contained this evening.
   Ms Guest said there were hopes weather changes would mean fire authorities would have a quieter weekend.
   "It is not going to be as hot and we don't expect winds to be as strong, with a higher relative humidity," she said.
   A total fire ban remains in place for the north eastern part of Victoria until midnight.
